etymSect.etym:
the tenth letter of the alphabet in English and other modern languages, is, in its origin, a comparatively late modification of the letter I. In the ancient Roman alphabet, I, besides its vowel value in ibīdem, mīlitis, had the kindred consonantal value of modern English Y, as in iactus, iam, Iouem, iūstus, adiūro, maior, peior. Some time before the 6th century, this y-sound had, by compression in articulation, and consequent development of an initial ‘stop’, become a consonantal diphthong, passing through a sound dj, akin to that of modern English di, de, in odious, hideous, to that represented in phonetic symbolization by dZ. At the same time, the original guttural sound of G, when followed by a front vowel, had changed to that of palatal g (ɟ, gj), and then, by an advance of the point of closure, had passed through that of dj, to the same sound dZ; so that i consonant and the so-called g ‘soft’ came to have, in the Romanic languages, the same identical value. In Italian, this new sound is represented by g before e and i, gi before a, o, and u. Thus, Latingestus, Iēsūs, iam, iocāre, iūdicem, are represented in Italian by gesto, Gesù, già, giocare, giudice. But in the other Romanic languages, the letter I was retained with the changed sound, so that, in these, i consonant and g ‘soft’ were equivalent symbols, distinguished only by derivation. In Old French the foregoing words were gest, Iesu, ia, ioer, iuge.
In Old English, i consonant, so far as it was used, had (as still in all the continental Germanic languages) its Latin value j, equivalent to Old Englishe, i, or e before certain vowels; thus we find iá, iól, iow, iú, iuoð, iung, as occasional spellings of the words commonly written eá, eól, eow, eó (ió, iú), eooð (iooð), eong (iong, iung). This was especially the case with foreign proper names and other words known through Latin, as Ianuarius, Iob, Iofes (= Jove), Iudéa, Iudéisc, iacinþ, and the ethnic name Iótas, Iútan (rarely Eotas), now rendered ‘Jutes’. But the French orthography introduced by the Norman Conquest brought in the Old French value of i consonant = g ‘soft’ dZ; a sound which English has ever since retained in words derived from that source, although in French itself the sound was subsequently, by loss of its first element, simplified to Z.
From the 11th to the 17th cent., then, the letter I i represented at once the vowel sound of i, and a consonant sound dZ, far removed from the vowel. Meanwhile, the minuteness and inconspicuousness of the small ı, and its liability, especially in cursive writing, to be confounded with one of the strokes of an adjacent letter, had led in mediæval Latin and general European writing, and thus also in English, to various scribal expedients in order to keep it distinct. (See I.) Among these, an initial ı was often prolonged above or below the line, or both; a final ı was generally prolonged below the line, and in both cases the prolonged part or ‘tail’ came at length in cursive writing to be terminated with a curve; thus arose the forms , , . The ‘dot’, used to individualize the minuscule i, was also used with the tailed form, and thus came the modern j, j. But this was at first merely a final form of i, used in Latin in such forms as ‘filij’, and in numerals, as j, ij, iij, vj, viij, xij. It was very little used in English, where y had previously been substituted for final i; and it was not till the 17th cent. that the device of utilizing the two forms of the letter, so that i, i, should remain as the vowel, and j, j, be used for the consonant, was established, and the capital forms of the latter, J, J, were introduced.The differentiation was made first in Spanish, where, from the very introduction of printing, we see j used for the consonant, and i only for the vowel. For the capitals, I had at first to stand for both (as it still does in German type, and in all varieties of Gothic or Black Letter); but before 1600 a capital J consonant began to appear in Spanish. (See, for example, Minsheu's Spanish Dictionary of 1599, where I and J are strictly distinguished, though the I and J words are put in one series.) In German typography, almost from the first, some printers employed a tailed form of the letter or j initially, to distinguish the consonant sound; but this was by no means generally established till much later. According to Watt (Bibliotheca Britannica), Louis Elzevir, who printed at Leyden 15951616, is generally credited with making the modern distinction of u and v, i and j, ‘which was shortly after followed by the introduction of U and J among the capitals by Lazarus Zetzner of Strasburg in 1619’. In England, individual attempts to differentiate i and j were made already in the 16th cent., as by Richard Day, who printed books in London after 1578, and George Bishop, who printed the translation of La Primaudaye's French Academie in 1586, with i, j, u, v, differentiated as in modern use, but had no capital J or U. The J j types are not used in the Bible of 1611, nor in the text of the Shakespeare Folio of 1623 (but see jig); these have I i for both values; but the latter has a capital Italic  in headlines in the proper names ohn, uliet, ulius, and in the colophon, list of actors, etc., thus showing a tendency to use this (in its origin merely an ornamental variety of I) as a J. In Cotgrave's French-English Dictionary printed in 1611 (and in the reprint of it in 1632), the Roman type used for the French has no capital J, and uses I with both values, but it has the small j which is regularly used in the French words: thus Iustice, Ajuster. On the other hand, the italic type, in which the English is printed, has no small j, and uses i for both vowel and consonant; it has the two capitals, I and , but uses them indiscriminately for the consonant: thus Ioyau: m. A Jewell; Ioyaulier: m. A Ieweller. Frequently  is used also for the vowel: thus Ingenieusement: ngeniously; Ingenieux: Ingenious. Thus even when the types I and  were at hand, their use was not yet regulated. But during the decade which followed 1625, J, j, J, j, appear to have been gradually added to all founts of type, and the present usage of restricting I i to the vowel, J j to the consonant appears to have been generally established soon after 1630. (See, under U and V, the similar differentiation of U u vowel, and V v consonant, from the earlier V v initial, u medial and final.)
But though the differentiation of I and J, in form and value, was thus completed before 1640, the feeling that they were, notwithstanding, merely forms of the same letter continued for many generations; a vestige of it is still seen in the practice of many persons, who in script write the I form (ℐ) for both ℐand , and in the omission by printers of J and U from the signatures of the sheets of books. In Dictionaries, the I and J words continued to be intermingled in one series down to the 19th cent. Dr. Johnson, indeed, under the letter I, says ‘I is in English considered both as a vowel and consonant; though, since the vowel and consonant differ in their form as well as sound, they may be more properly accounted two letters’. Nevertheless, he proceeds to treat them practically as one, his first word I being followed by Jabber; Jam by Iambick, and this by Jangle; while the three last words of I are Juxtaposition, Ivy, Jymold. The same practice was followed by Todd, and by Richardson 1820, and even in some later dictionaries. Jodrell in 1820, Webster in 1828, separate I and J, as independent letters. The name of the letter, now jaydZeI, was formerly jydZaI, rhyming with I, and corresponding to Frenchji; this is still common in Scotland and elsewhere.
In printing manuscripts or reprinting books produced before the differentiation of I and J, the earlier I has been treated in two different ways. The earlier editors, in most cases, introduced the modern usage into their texts, changing the I of the archetype, when it stood for the consonant, into J. Later editors more usually aim at reproducing the actual form of the original, and retain I with its twofold value. As quotations are, in the main, from printed editions of MSS., and in some cases from later editions of printed books, they necessarily reflect these differences of editorial practice, and often show J before the 17th cent.; it is to be remembered that this is usually due to the edition quoted, not to the original scribe or printer. But in the chronological lists of ‘Forms’, which precede the Etymology and Senses, these editorial J's have been disregarded, and the contemporary I alone given down to the date when J was actually in use.In some modern editions of MS. or Black-letter books, in which the minuscule i of the original text is reproduced, we yet find a capital J introduced. This arises probably from the circumstance that the MS. or Italic , or Black-letter , is more like a J than an I in appearance, and is actually still used both for I and J.
No word beginning with J is of Old English derivation. Many are from Latin, chiefly through French; some from Greek, and a few from Hebrew and Arabic. There are also numerous modern words from distant languages, Eastern or Western, as jaguar, jalap, jerboa, jungle, junk. Besides these, many familiar or colloquial words of recent appearance and obscure history begin with this letter. On account of the phonetic equivalence of i consonant (i.e. j) and g ‘soft’ in words from Romanic, while in native English words, as girl, get, g was ‘hard’, there was a considerable tendency in Middle English to substitute i (= j) for g in words from French, as in gemme, iemme, gentil, ientyl, gest, iest, (and occasionally a counter tendency to use g for i (j), as in iet, jet, geat, maiestie, majesty, magestie), of which traces still remain in gest, jest, sergeant, serjeant, jelly from Frenchgelée, etc.
The regular and practically uniform sound of the letter J in English is the consonantal diphthong dZ. In the word hallelujah (also spelt halleluiah) it has the sound of Roman i-consonant j. The same sound is retained in proper names or alien terms from German and other languages in which the Roman value of j is retained, as Jena"je:na, Jaeger, Joachim, Jungfrau, junker, Janos, Jaroslav, Jassy. In a few French words, distinctly recognized as alien, j has the French sound Z, as déjeuner, jeu d'esprit. In the transliteration of Oriental names, as Jāt, Jehangir, Jenghiz, Juggernaut, Jumna, etc., j is used with its English value.

s4.def: The letter. The plural appears as Js, J's, js, j's.

q.qt: Now as concerning I consonant, which oftentimes vniustly vsurpeth the sound and place of G: me thinke it hath small reason: or rather I may say it is verie absurd, and much against both Art and reason.
j somewhat like the French Desja, joieux, jouer, but best like the Hebrew ש with his point on the right horne, or sh in English, as Ojo, osho.

There be three kindes of I in the Spanish, that is, small i, Greeke y, and j, Jota or consonant.‥ J jota or j consonant, which this toong taketh of the Arabique, is pronounced as in French Jamais, Deja, Jehan, in English like sh, as Jardin, a gardin, shardin.
X is‥pronounced like J consonant, and the Spaniard often writeth one for another.

For distinctiones of both sound and symbol, I wald commend the symbol and name of i and u to the voual sound;‥the symboles of j and v to the latin consonantes, and their names to be jod and vau; as, vain jestes.
And j, for difference of the voual i, written with a long tail, I wald wish to be called jod or je.
J consonant has invariably the same sound with that of g in giant; as jade, jet, jilt.
Esau‥carved E. and J. into a true lover's knot under the handle of it.
We carry the tails of our J's‥below the line.

s4.def: A curve or figure of the shape of the letter.

q.qt: A spur‥ran out toward the west and formed a large ‘J’ with the curve facing the south.

q.qt: The ink-pot‥with an old J nib in it stiff with rust.
A Visit to the J-Pen Club.‥ Holding conclave with a group of brand-new Jays.
What pen do you write with? Do you use a J?

s4.def: Rarely used like the preceding letters to express serial order. In the signatures of the sheets of books, etc., the old order of the Roman alphabet, H, I, K, is usually retained. In the alphabetic designations of the batteries of the Royal Artillery A, B, C, etc., J is used for the tenth.

q.qt: Field Artillery, 1st Brigade, A Battery, Dinapore;‥I, Ahmedabad; J, Dublin; K, Aldershot.
Horse Artillery‥A Battery, Umballa;‥I, Mhow; J, Bangalore; K, Rawal Pindi.
MS. J‥is at present in the library of Dupplin.
The transport Ujina sailed for Durban with J Battery Royal Horse Artillery and spare horses.

s4.def: As a Roman numeral j was formerly used as a final form of i in j, ij, vj, and the like; this is retained in medical prescriptions.

bibMain.loc: 179 ℞ ladani ℥ j, & resolue it in ℥ iiij of oile of mirtilles.

s6.def: In Math. and Physics, J is used to denote the Jacobian; also Joule's mechanical equivalent of heat; for j in Quaternions, see I (the letter) 6.
In Electr.j is used (in place of the mathematical symbol i, which is used for electric current) to represent √(− 1), or an angular displacement of 90°.

q.qt: The next Paper was by Mr. C. P. Steinmetz on ‘Complex Quantities and their Application in Electrical Engineering’. This Paper contained a novel method of the treatment of alternating currents.‥ The device is to introduce the letter j in the expression of the sine curve, at first simply as a distinguishing index without mathematical meaning, and afterward as j = √(− 1).

It can be shown‥by ordinary trigonometry that the components of a line whose length is I√R² + X² and which is θ degrees ahead of I, where θ is the angle whose tangent is X/R, are e1 = Ri1 − Xi11 and e11 = Xi1 + Ri11. Therefore the term j²Xi11‥must be equal to −Xi11, or, in other words, we must have: j² = −1.
Considering j as a vector-operator, it is a means whereby a length in one direction is rotated anticlockwise by 90°.
Since j2A = −A‥, then j2 = −1 or j = √(−1).
The j is always placed to the left in the product. This practice helps avoid the overlooking of a j-term when real and j-terms are being grouped.

s6.ch_firstSource: London, Edinburgh and Dublin Philosophical Magazine
s6.def:
In Physics J and j represent quantized angular momentum.j was first used by A. Sommerfeld (in Ann. d. Physik (1923) LXX. 33), in place of nj, which had been used by W. Heisenberg (in Zeitschr. f. Physik (1922) VIII. 274) in place of Sommerfeld's original symbol ni, which he introduced (in Atombau u. Spektrallinien (ed. 3, 1922) vi. 446 and Zeitschr. f. Physik (1922) VIII. 269) as an empirical ‘inner’ quantum number (German innere Quantenzahl) in describing the Zeeman effect. As this was interpreted in terms of later theory, j became the quantum number of the total angular momentum of an electron, corresponding to the resultant of its spin s and orbital momentum l; J is used similarly for an assemblage of electrons, and in molecular spectroscopy is the quantum number for angular momentum due to rotation of a molecule as a whole. Apart from these specific uses, j and J are often used as symbols for a general angular momentum.
jj-coupling, an approximation used in the quantum theory of the atom when the spin-orbit interaction of individual electrons is large compared with the remaining electrostatic interaction between one electron and another, so that spin and orbital angular momenta may be coupled to give a resultant j for each electron, and the resultants in turn coupled to give the total angular momentum J of the electrons. Cf. LS-couplingL6b.

q.qt: The X-ray atomic levels may be conveniently classified by means of three quantum numbers—n (total), k (azimuthal), and j (inner).
In the normal, Russell-Saunders, or LS coupling scheme (l1l2) (s1s2) = (LS) = J.‥ In the jj coupling scheme (l1s1) (l2s2) = (j1j2) = J.
The resultant angular momentum of the molecule (quantum number J).
As J increases and the molecule rotates faster, it stretches.
Consider the case of two spins (or angular momenta) j1 and j2.

In the lower-lying configurations of neutral atoms the j-j coupling approximation is not often found, in other words the conditions for small electrostatic interaction are not often satisfied, even in heavy elements.

joule.

sub.def: a proprietary name for excavators and other earth-moving equipment made by the firm of J. C. Bamford (Excavators) Ltd.

A query has recently arisen in my traffic section regarding the necessity for a provisional licence holder to be accompanied when driving a J.C.B. excavator on a road.
Dump trucks and JCBs are already flattening the site.

The editor rejected the frivolous attentions of his audience, and left the J.C.R.
The Student Council received the support‥of the vast majority of JCRs.

q.qt: JICTAR—Joint Industry Committee for Television Advertising Research—embraces the Incorporated Society of British Advertisers, the Independent Television Companies Association and the Institute of Practitioners in Advertising.
JICTAR has replaced TAM as the index of response.
Other problems include the possibility that in rejuvenating the old JICTAR sample for BARB's birth last year, some faithful heavy viewers were lost and non-addicts put in their places.

sub.def: just noticeable difference.

q.qt: The just noticeable difference, often called the ‘j.n.d.’, between the stimuli of two sensations.
Rubbers could be compared with one another with about three times as small a j.n.d. as that found for bitumens.

One of the fundamental principles of JIT manufacturing is the use of daily rates to regulate the flow of material through the factory.

s6.def: An act of jabbing; an abrupt blow with something pointed, or (in Boxing slang) with the fist.

q.qt: Jab, the act of pricking in this way i.e. sharply.
Giving the fire a jab with the poker.
A short, sharp, terrible jab of the masked man's unengaged left hand.
The chief's son‥made a tentative jab with a spear at the white man.

s6.def: An injection with a hypodermic needle. slang (orig. U.S.).

q.qt: Jab, current amongst morphine and cocaine fiends. A hypodermic injection.
Receiving the hypodermic jab intended for the bullock.
Can't you give me a jab of something to keep me going?
The visitor must‥take precautions and submit to a variety of jabs.

s4.def: A radio signal of momentary duration. colloq.

q.qt: Another film I saw was of the flight of a jab of wireless energy on its journey from the East End to King's College, Strand.
For this purpose they devised a radio transmitter which sent out very short pulses, or jabs, of radio energy.

s4.def: A critical or mocking remark. Freq. with at.

q.qt: Who was the inspiration for these verbal jabs?
He also could not resist taking a good-natured jab at the colossus to the north.
Many of Moore's most quotable jabs at the romantic figure of the poet are more suggestive of affection than of a desire to afflict.
He had the habit of making verbal jabs at the government.
Domi also threw a jab at those who blasted the Leafs for not landing a marquee free agent.

etymSect.etym: var., originally Scots, of job

s6.def: trans. To thrust with the end or point of something; to poke roughly; to stab.

q.qt: To Jab, to prick sharply.
The hog‥being jabbed with a spear.
M. Mendès got jabbed in the lower part of his chest, seriously if not fatally.

s6.def: To thrust (something) with an abrupt blow (into a thing or person).

q.qt: I disapprove of jabbing the spear into a hog.
Jabbing the point of his penknife into the writing pad.

s6.def: absol. or intr. To stab.

q.qt: When alone, it is fair to jab.
The Khusru Kheyl jab upwards from below, remember.

s6.def: trans. To give (a person) a stabbing blow with the fist. Also fig.

q.qt: Jab him, if you can, with your left.
Time and again he jabbed and patted Smith cleverly on the nose with his left hand.
One may be shafted or jabbed by the opposite sex, a professor‥or anyone else for any real or imagined injury.

s6.def: trans. and intr. To inject or inoculate (a person) with a hypodermic needle; to use (a hypodermic needle) to make an injection.

q.qt: To jab, to take drugs hypodermically.
Be jabbed, to be inoculated or vaccinated.
Not all jazz-players smoke marijuana or opium, or sniff snow or jab a vein.
Dr Wadd‥dashed in with a hypodermic syringe of digitalis and jabbed it so hastily, though successfully, into the back of one of his hands that it raised a large lump.
Smith-road primary was jabbed. Why not our school?
Some stiffs uses mud but coke don't need any jabbin', cookin', or flops. You can hit it an' go.

s4.def: The act of jabbering; rapid and indistinct or unintelligible talk; gabble, chatter; gibberish.

q.qt: Who only differ from their Brother Brutes in Houyhnhnmland, because they use a Sort of Jabber.
A sea-port jabber, formed‥by the mishmash of a hundred dialects.
He‥was utterly ignorant of any language but his own; despised all foreigners, and detested their ‘jabber’.
Prepared for what she called a ‘jabber’.

etymSect.etym: apparently onomatopoeic, with the form of a frequentative; with jabber, jabble, compare gab, gabber, gabble; also yabber; the phonetic relation between these is not clear. An earlier form in the Promptorium MSS. is javer, which in Pynson's ed. became jaber.

s6.def: intr. To talk rapidly and indistinctly or unintelligibly; to speak volubly and with little sense; to chatter, gabble, prattle. Often applied, in contempt or derision, to the speaking of a language which is unintelligible to the hearer.

q.qt: Iangelyn or iaberyn Harl. MS. iaveryn, garrulo, blatero.
Tateryn or iaberyn Harl. MS. iaueryn, or speke wythe owte resone, garrio, blatero.
Which Infant‥doth not jabber so strangely, but that she is perfectly understood by her Parent.
To Jabber, a word vulgarly used for to prattle, chat, or talk.
He had brought a gentleman‥who could jabber with her in French.
We have got two Flemish servants, and you should hear them jabbering.

s6.def: To utter inarticulate sounds rapidly and volubly; to chatter, as monkeys, birds, etc.; to gibber or jibber.

q.qt: Allanson made some sound‥as if attempting to speak, but his tongue refused its office, and he only jabbered.
The fool who jabbered at his feet, the monkey which grinned at the back of his chair.
In the huge trees the monkeys hung jabbering.
On the top of the crag the sea-fowl were jabbering.

s4.def: trans. To speak or utter rapidly and indistinctly; to express by jabbering. Often contemptuously = to speak (a foreign language), with the implication that it is unintelligible to the hearer.

q.qt: Whatsoeuer the Iewes would iaber or iangle agayn.
They must‥jabber their Credos and Pater-Nosters at home.
He did not know what Travelling was good for, but to teach a Man‥to jabber French, and to talk against Passive Obedience.
A poor idiot,‥used to come every day to the churchyard, to‥jabber in broken expressions his grief.

sub.def: jabbering crow, a small species of crow common in Jamaica (Corvus Jamaicensis).

q.qt: Taterynge or iaberinge Harl. MS. iauerynge, Winch. MS. iaperynge, garritus.
Latyne Iabberynge and wawlynge, accordynge to the offyce of saynt Antonynes personage.
His Singing-Boys with their alternate Jabberings and Mouthings.
'Twas chatt'ring, grinning, mouthing, jabb'ring all.
Jabb'ring spectres o'er her traces glide.
To study the jabberings of monkeys.

sub.def: in a jabbering manner (Hyde Clarke, 1855).

s4.def: Corruption of Jesus, used expletively (see bejab(b)ers).

q.qt: By jappers, we were tould he was the boy.
‘Be Jabers!’ said the girl, ‘is that the way you feel?’
‘Can you hit that man?’ The gunner replied, ‘Be japers, I'll ate what's left of him.’

s4.def: The name of the fabulous monster in Lewis Carroll's poem Jabberwocky. Hence in allusive and extended uses, esp. ‘incoherent or nonsensical expression’.

q.qt: The Jabberwock, with eyes of flame, Came whiffling through the tulgey wood.
It was the strangest jumble of vowels and consonants I had ever met.‥ It was some maniac talking Jabberwock to himself.
The movable mounting for the observer's gun in the rear cockpit was a weird contraption like a giant catapult.‥ We called it the Christmas Tree, the Heath Robinson, the Jabberwock, etc..

sub.def: (intr.) to write, speak, etc., in jabberwocky style.

q.qt: His sc. Skelton's tendency to jabberwock (like Pound or Eliot, Skelton was a polylingual versifier).
He jabberwockied, pulling furiously at his ear-lobe as he talked.

sub.def: invented language, meaningless language, nonsensical behaviour; also as , nonsensical, meaningless, topsy-turvy.

q.qt: Those exceptional modern folk who write with equal ease in the ordinary left-to-right manner and in ‘Jabberwocky’ fashion‥right to left.
From ‘Jabberwocky’ it is but a short step to the old-fashioned nursery-rhyme.
The dreaming mind does not usually speak—and when it does, it is more likely to express itself in the looking-glass language of ‘Jabberwocky’ than in anything resembling ordinary speech.
It is all very Jabberwocky, and so far the writers of the movement surrealism have the advantage of the artists.
Realizing in a short time that I was not in the least interested in all this jabberwocky, and thinking of Mona waiting for me to lunch with her, I suddenly interrupted him.
Sometimes, to confuse the issue,‥he would indulge in his own subtle form of jabberwocky.

bibMain.w: Young Man, I think you're Dying

q.qt: He was going to wear her down, intimidate her, tame and train her to obey, and a whole lot of other jabberwocky which he couldn't‥remember now.
Worcester first period teapot stand ‘Jabberwocky pattern’.

s4.def: A slight agitated movement of water or other liquid; a splashing or dashing in small waves or ripples.

q.qt: There is a perpetual ‘jabble’ against the cliffs on this coast.
A plash and jabble of conflicting waters.
The steamer jumped, and the black buoys were dancing in the jabble.
Carmichael's mind was in a jabble that day.

s4.def: = jabber

q.qt: To Babil, garrire. To Brabil, idem, multum loqui. To Iabil, idem.
Thousands of birds, all jabbling and dabbling, and paddling.

etymSect.etym: apparently onomatopoeic, with frequentative or diminutive ending -le; compare dabble.

s6.def: trans. To shake or mix up together (quot. 1760); to shake up or agitate (a liquid), to cause to splash.
intr. To splash, plash, dash in small waves or ripples.

q.qt: All mix'd‥by‥jabling them well together in a Cloth.
To Jabble, 1. To cause agitation of the sea, as when the wind rises. 2. To agitate the liquid contents of a dish or vessel, so as to cause spilling.
The rippling tide‥jabbling along the side of the boat.

etymSect.etym: A pet-name or by-name, used as a familiar equivalent of John; in Middle EnglishJakke, Jacce, Jacke, a disyllable: compare the analogous Cebbe, Colle, Dawe, Geffe, Gibbe, Grigge, Hicke, Hobbe, Hogge, Hudde, Judde, Symme, Thomme, Watte, mentioned along with Jacke, in Gower's Vox Clamantis, i. 783–91. The actual origin is disputed. It has been generally assumed to be the same word as FrenchJacques, in Old French also Jaques, Jaqves (*Jacbes late LatinˈJacobus, for Jacōbus, GreekἸάκωβος Jacob) James; also a familiar name for a peasant, a man of low social status (compare Jacquerie). But it has been used in English from its earliest appearance as a by-name of Johan, Jan, John; and a strong case has been made out by E. W. B. Nicholson, M.A., Bodley's Librarian (The Pedigree of Jack and of various allied names, 1892), for its actual origination as a pet-form of that word. Compare especially the recognized diminutives Jankin and Jackin (as contained in the surnames Jacken (1327), Jackins, Jackinson), and the relation between Dick and Dickin, Rob and Robin, etc. The Scottish equivalent form of the name is Jock, but this has not the transferred senses of Jack.

s2.header: Applied to a man, or the figure of one.

s6.def: (As proper noun.) A familiar by-form of the name John; hence, a generic proper name for any representative of the common people.Occurs as a fore-name in the Worcestershire Lay Subsidy roll of 127682, which has also the variant or derivative Jacky. Jakkes occurs as a surname in Hants in 1279, and Jak as a surname in Norfolk in 1297.

q.qt: Saue Iacke þe Iogelour and Ionete of þe stuyues.
Therwhile he hath his fulle packe, They seie, ‘A good felawe is Iacke’.
Mos enim est‥Saxonum‥verba ac nomina transformare‥ut pro Thoma Tomme sive Tomlin, pro Iohanne Iankin sive Iacke.
Jacke would be a gentleman if he could speake frenche.
We vse the like termes by way of pleasant familiaritie‥as‥Mall for Mary, Nell for Elner: Iack for Iohn, Robin for Robert.
Deckers but Tom; nor May, nor Middleton. And hee's now but Jacke Foord, that once were John.
Well Jack, the old Prig is dead at last.
Jack, Tom, and Harry have no existence in the eye of the law, except as included in some form or other of the permanent property of the realm.
Thus did I become‥the acknowledged‥‘Poor Jack of Greenwich’.

In 1379‥we find a Nicholaus Jakson Hughson, who must be the son of a man entered as Johannes Hughson. It seems impossible to avoid the conclusion that this Johannes Hughson was called Jak by his neighbours.

s6.def: In collocation with the female name Gill or Jill: see gill2.

q.qt: And I wole kepe the feet this tyde Thow ther come both Iakke and Gylle.
For Iak nor for Gill Will I turne my face.
Al is wel. Iak shal haue gill.
Som songe of Jenken and Julyan for there mede.
Princes are brav'd by Jack and Jill.
A good Jack makes a good Gill.
If Gill was a shrew, it was because Jack did not, as in duty bound, stop her mouth with a kiss!

sub.def: familiar name for a Cornishman: see cousin5b.

q.qt: Cousin Jack Tressider, an opulent Cornish miner.
A short man, whose blue-black curly hair and deep-set eyes betrayed the ‘Cousin Jack’.

s6.def: Used as a form of address to an unknown person. colloq. (orig. U.S.).

q.qt: Jack (American), it is common among schoolboys in Philadelphia to address a stranger as Jack.
Jack is still very frequent among ‘the common people’ when, in addressing a stranger, one wishes to avoid the abruptness caused by omitting the unknown name.
Jack, that man had them rolling in the aisles.
Dawn taps yer winder sc. window‥another day before yiz sc. you, Jack.
Jack, term of address by one male to another.

s6.def: (As a common noun.) A man of the common people; a lad, fellow, chap; esp. a low-bred or ill-mannered fellow, a ‘knave’. Obs.

q.qt: A common poyncte of pleasure doyng, that euery iacke vseth.
They send them sc. geese to the medowes‥vnder the custodie of some little small Iacke, who may keepe them from going‥into any forbidden places.
A mad-cap ruffian and a swearing Iacke.
A halter stretch thee, such ill-tutord jacks Poyson the fame of Patrons.
But Mr. Unbelief was a nimble Jack, him they could never lay hold of.
Familiar both with peers and Jacks.

s6.def: Phr. to play the jack: to play the knave, to do a mean trick. Obs.

q.qt: If you were not resolu'd to play the Iacks, what need you study for new subiects, purposely to abuse your betters?
Your Fairy‥Has done little better then plaid the Iacke with vs.
Sir R. Brookes overtook us coming to town; who hath played the Jacke with us all and is a fellow that I must trust no more.

s6.def: every man jack (see man21).
A policeman or detective; a military policeman. Cf. John1c. slang.

q.qt: A policeman, a fly, Jack,‥crusher, peeler.
A couple of men who were in plain clothes in the tap-room of a public-house, and were suspected by the ‘gaffer’ of being ‘Jacks’.
Jack, a military policeman.
Blue‥looked up and saw two Jacks waiting. ‘Where are you going?’ demanded one M.P.
Jacks, military police.
We all had to stand there with a crowd of jacks in plain clothes standing round.
You're not going to believe it. I haven't told all to the jacks naturally.
These county coppers‥couldn't get their minds unhooked from the words ‘New Scotland Yard’—as if every jack in the Metropolitan Police District worked from there.

s6.def: Slang phr. on one's jack = on one's own, alone (short for on one's Jack Jones34e).

q.qt: Jack, on his: on his own.
Michael went off on his jack an' left me wid de bloody baby.
Tell you the details and then you'll do the gaff on your jack‥or else turn grass.
You're off on your jack then?
I thought I could go sneaking in there all on my jack and bring out the evidence.

s6.def: (As proper or common noun.) A familiar appellation for a sailor. Also Jack-tar, q.v.

q.qt: Hollanders‥, the Broom at the main Top-mast head‥; The English took it down, and laid it most sadly upon Jack-Sailors breech.
Let us e'en turn about, and view honest Jack the Sailor.
Here he and his Brother Jacks lie pelting each other with Sea-Wit.
We drank tea‥on board.‥ Some of their Jacks played very well upon the violin.
There's a sweet little cherub that sits up aloft, To keep watch for the life of poor Jack.
There's nothing for Jack to do but to obey orders, and I went up upon the yard.

bibMain.w: Narr. Earl of Elgin's Mission China & Japan

q.qt: Our Jacks presented a most grotesque appearance as they returned to their ships.

s6.def: Phr. Jack ashoresee quot. 1909. slang.

q.qt: Jack afloat and ashore.
Jack ashore, Jack elevated—practically drunk, and larky.

It was long after the sea-chapter of my life had been closed, but it is difficult to discard completely the characteristics of half a lifetime, and it was in something of the Jack-ashore spirit that I dropped a five-franc piece into the sauceboat.
Jack Ashore does not check bills.

s6.def: Colloq. phr. I'm all right, Jack: a saying indicating selfish complacency on the part of the speaker.

q.qt: It's ‘Damn you Jack—I'm all right!’ with you chaps.
They dodged as much work as possible and generally assumed the manner ‘I'm all right Jack’.
Private life or I'm all right Jack.
This ‘I'm all right, Jack’ attitude towards such relatives is deplorable.
He adopted an ‘I'm all right, Jack’ attitude in leaving his convoy.
Right now it is, as I said before, dog eat dog.‥ I'm all right, Jack, damn you.

s6.def: Variously applied to a serving-man or male attendant, a labourer, a man who does odd jobs, etc. See also Cheap Jackcheap, steeple jacksteeple2a, etc.

q.qt: Having a chat with the ‘jack’, who‥seems to be wholly incapable of doing any thing but lounging about.
A grizzled male creature, the ‘Jack’ of the little causeway.
He a blind man became skilful at bowls and bribed the jacks to give him hints as to the direction he was to throw.
I asked Mr. Morris by what stages his steeplejacks attained the handsome sum of 5l. per week. His answer is that a jack (unless already trained) begins his career by labouring.

s6.def: Colloq. shortening of lumberjack (lumber2). N. Amer.

q.qt: Every jack's a cant-hook man.‥ They do some heavy loggin'.
The breaking up of the lumber camps and the streaming southward of thousands of ‘jacks’.
The red-bearded jack came on again, head low and shielded.
The jacks who felled the trees and the workers who stripped them were called piqueteurs.
I had to fire thirty Jacks last fall.‥ Lumberjacks.

s6.def: Cards. Name for the knave of trumps in the game of all-fours; hence gen. any one of the knaves.

q.qt: This game‥is called All Fours, from highest, lowest, jack, and game, which is the set as some play it.
He turns up a Card, which is Trump: if Jack (and that is any knave) it is one to the dealer.
A jack at cards.
He calls the knaves, Jacks, this boy!

sub.def: ‘a game of cards resembling all-fours’ (Cent. Dict.).

q.qt: Here is the down-east Yankee‥turning his native cunning to account at poker and California jack.
His losses at Californian Jack‥were my gains.
For two hours they sat and played California jack in plain sight of the street.

s4.def: A figure of a man which strikes the bell on the outside of a clock. (See Jack of the clock3.)As the name of a mechanical contrivance, this sense is transitional to the next group.

q.qt: It. payed for the settyng of Jak with the hangyng of his bell and mendyng his hond, iiijd.
King. Well, let it strike. Buck. Whie let it strike? King. Because that like a Iacke 1623 Iack thou keepst the stroke Betwixt thy begging and my meditation.
This is the night, nine the houre, and I the Iacke that giues warning.
If Powles Iacks bee once vp wt their elbowes, and quarrelling to strike eleuen.
On the East side is a dial of near ten feet square, with quarter jacks under it.
There was an ancient clock in Old St. Paul's, with Jacks to strike the hours.

s2.header: Applied to things which in some way take the place of a lad or man, or save human labour; also more vaguely to other things with which one has to do.

s3.header: To separate contrivances, machines, utensils, etc.

s4.def: A machine for turning the spit in roasting meat; either wound up like a clock or actuated by the draught of heated air up the chimney (smoke-jack).

q.qt: The iacke whiche turneth the broche.
It stood altogether like a Germane clock, or an English Iack or Turne-spit, vpon skrewes and vices.
The winding up of a iacke is better then musicke to his eares in Lent.
After supper we looked over‥his Wooden Jack in his Chimny that go with the Smoak; which indeed is very pretty.
Our Roasting is not magnificent, for we have no Jack.
Hugh‥sent it twirling round like a roasting jack.
I have hung it‥to the bottle-jack, so that when I wind it up, it will keep turning round.
A smoke-jack, by means of which, several spits, if needful, can be kept turning at the same time.

s4.def: A name for various contrivances consisting (solely or essentially) of a roller or winch.

q.qt: A Iack of wood for a towel and bason.
You should finde some Iacks faulty, and some cogges missing, whereby the wheele of Iustice is hindered in his circular course.
The Wood work belonging to the Jack, is a Barrel, or Spit-wheel and a Handle of the Winch.
There were Sluices‥wound up and down by a Jack.
Iron Jacks, sometimes used instead of the table-wheel or back-frame wheel, differ from the latter by having an iron wheel with cogs, which work in the whirls.

s4.def: A wooden frame for sawing wood upon.

q.qt: A Iack for to saw vpon, fewell for fier.
A Jack,‥a Horse whereon they saw Wood.
Jack is used also for a horse or wooden frame to saw timber upon.

s6.def: A machine, usually portable, for lifting heavy weights by force acting from below; in the commonest form, having a rack and a pinion wheel or screw and a handle turned by hand. Also called lifting-jack (see lifting-jacklifting2) and jack-screw (see jack-screw).

q.qt: Jack,‥an Engine used for the removing and commodious placing of great Timber.
The machine may be applied as a jack to raise great weights a little way from the ground.
Fig. 341 represents the common or simple hand jack.

bibMain.w: Official Descr. & Illustr. Catal. Great Exhib.

q.qt: Hydraulic lifting jack for railway engines and carriages.
Double-jack.
See jack-screw.

s6.def: See quots.

q.qt: Jack‥for supporting the axletree of a cart in order to remove one of the wheels.
Jack, a contrivance, consisting of a lever and fulcrum, used in washing carriages, to lift one side so that the wheel‥may run round freely; sometimes called a ‘carriage-jack’.

s4.def: A contrivance for pulling off boots; a bootjack. rare or Obs. (exc. in the compound).

q.qt: He pull'd off his Boots‥upon the Frame of a Table, or else upon a Jack.

So foot-boys, who had frequently the common name of Jack given them, were kept to turn the spit, or to pull off their master's boots; but when instruments were invented for both these services, they were both called jacks.

s4.def: Mining.

s6.def: ‘A kind of water-engine, turned by hand, used in mines. Staff.’ (Halliwell.)
A wooden wedge or gad used in mining for assisting in the cleaving of strata.
(See quot. 1851.)

bibMain.w: Gloss. Terms Coal Trade Northumberland & Durham

q.qt: Whilst two pits or a pit and a staple are being sunk simultaneously by means of two gins, one of them, to prevent mistakes, is usually called a jack.
Jack,‥a wedge.
Jack,‥10. A wooden wedge used by miners to separate rocks after blasting.

s4.def: In many names of instruments in which it is combined with a defining word: e.g. lifting-jack, pegging-jack, shackle-jack, thill-jack, etc. q.v. Also builder's jack, a temporary staging or bracket projecting outwards from a window, used in cleaning, painting, or repairing; also called window-jack (E. H. Knight Pract. Dict. Mech.1874). round jack, ‘a stand for holding a hat while the brim is trimmed to shape’ (Cent. Dict.).

s3.header: To parts of instruments or machines.

s4.def: In the virginal, spinet, and harpsichord: An upright piece of wood fixed to the back of the key-lever, and fitted with a quill which plucked the string as the jack rose on the key's being pressed down. (By Shakespeare and some later writers erron. applied to the key.)Also applied to a similar upright piece terminating in the ‘tangent’ in a clavichord, or serving to raise the damper, or the hammer, in early pianofortes; sometimes also to the hopper, or a part of it, in a modern pianoforte.

q.qt: Saltarélli, the iacks of a paire of virginals.
Her teeth chatterd in her head, and leapt vp and down like Virginal-Iacks.
How oft‥Do I enuie those Iackes that nimble leape, To kisse the tender inward of thy hand.
Like the iacke of a virginall, which stricketh the sounding corde.
The Treble Notes of a Harpsichord would be overpowered by the Bass ones, did not the Bits of Cloth affixed to the Jacks check the Vibrations of the Strings in due time.

The merit of introducing in the square piano the ‘hopper’—a jack with a spring and working in a notch or nose forming the front part of a lever, technically known as the ‘underhammer’—belongs to John Geib, who in 1786 took out a patent for this improvement.

s4.def: In various machines.

s6.def: An oscillating lever, such as those in a stocking-frame or knitting-machine.

q.qt: The stockingframe‥the wheel by whose motion the jacks are drawn together upon the needles.
The stocking-frame invented by the Rev. William Lea, or Lee‥in 1589, was very simple, with jacks only.
The stocking-frame has a series of vibrating levers, called jacks, which‥throw the‥yarn into such curvatures as enable the needles to form the loops.

s6.def: Weaving. = heck-boxheck2.

q.qt: Each human being who watches beside jack or power loom feels more or less intensely that it is a solemn thing to live.
s.v.

s6.def: Spinning. A coarse bobbin and fly-frame operating on the sliver from the carding-machine and passing the product to the fine roving-machine, or fitting it therefor.

q.qt: s.v.

s6.def: Telegr., etc. A socket or receptacle having one or more pairs of terminals and designed so that insertion of a suitable plug enables a device to be quickly introduced into a circuit.

q.qt: The effect of inserting a plug in one of the jacks is that the end of the plug lifts the line spring r from pin y.
The home sections and the multiple panels are made up of ‘jacks’, mounted in strips.
The ‘jacks’ consist of two springs of unequal length and a collar or socket.
The last three jacks have filament controlling contacts by which the insertion of the plug automatically lights the filaments.
Lloyd's AM/FM digital clock radio.‥ Features‥earphone jack and solid-state circuitry.
Is there another jack in this room?‥ Can you get another phone and plug it in?

s4.def: In carriages: see quot. 1794.

q.qt: Spring Jack. Fig. 11. This is a small engine fixed to the bottom of the spring.‥ Its use is to heighten or lower the body.
A pair of spring jacks.

s3.header: To things of smaller than the normal size.

s4.def: A very small amount; the least bit; a whit. Obs.colloq.

q.qt: Iacke or whitte nicquet, as I wyll nat gyve you a whyt.

s6.def: In the game of Bowls, A smaller bowl placed as a mark for the players to aim at.

q.qt: Was there euer man had such lucke? when I kist the Iacke vpon an vp-cast, to be hit away?
The marke which they ayme at hath sundry names and Epithites, as a Blocke, a Iacke, and a Mistris.
If I have a bowl in my hand and want it to touch the jack at the other end of the green.
A bias that should reach the jack.
The jack shall not be changed during a game, except by mutual consent of the players.

s6.def: = jack-stone; usu. pl.; (also) a game played with these (see also quot. 1908).

q.qt: Playing at quoits, tops, marbles, tic-tac-toe, jacks, knuckle-bones.
Jack,‥a piece of metal with five tines or protuberances, used in the game of jacks. Jacks, an indoor catching game played with small five-tined metal pieces.
‘Jacks’ is a game in which throwing and catching are not the main centers of interest; rather are the attention and interest focussed on what is done between catches.
Do you know how to skate?‥ Did you ever play jacks?

s4.def: slang.

s6.ch_firstSource: New Dictionary of the Canting Crew
s6.def: A farthing. ? Obs.

q.qt: Jack, a Farthing.

s6.def: A counter made to resemble a sovereign: so half-jack.

q.qt: The ‘card-counters’, or‥the ‘small coins’, are now of a very limited sale. The slang name for these articles is ‘Jacks’ and ‘Half Jacks’.
It is hardly possible that any one who had ever received a sovereign in payment, could be deceived by‥a Jack.
Jacks, and half-jacks, card counters, resembling in size and appearance sovereigns and half-sovereigns.

s6.def: Money. slang (orig. U.S.).

q.qt: The‥verbal wealth of the United States language is illustrated in an inquiry for a loan of money; by using any of the following words in conjunction with the inquiry, Have you any‥Jacks, etc..
The fans which paid their jack to see a fight would be gypped.
This way every bastardly tourist with a little jack thinks he can hire you.
I hadn't that much jack.‥ I worked a passage home.
I asked him‥to think of the new suits he could get‥when the jack came in.
