s6.def: slang. Also jacks, jax. Five pounds; a five-pound note. Cf. Jack's alive3.

q.qt: I'll bet you a jacks that I nick you.
Jack, five pounds.
‘That one,’ says the dealer from Islington, ‘that one we know she died in; so it'll cost you a jax.’‥ Five quid for a shroud; cheap at the price.
‘Couldn't lend me a Jack's, Terry, could you?’ ‘Sure.’ He gave the DS a fiver.
From under a pottery sugar jar‥protruded two jacks.

s4.def: A quarter of a pint: = the imperial gill, or half the northern gill (q.v.). regional.

q.qt: Jack, a measure, and Gill, another.
Jack, half a pint. Yorks.
To a pound of sugar put a jack of water.
Jack, a quarter of a pint measure.
Jack, a quarter of a pint measure, and the quantity contained in one. Also in Holderness, Sheffield, Mid. Yorksh. Gloss.

s4.def: Building. A small brick or ‘bat’ used as a closer at the end of a course. ? Obs.

q.qt: Imagine FEG to be a Stretcher, or a Stretching Archytrave‥and Imagining it to be thus divided; then EF is called a Header; or a heading Archytrave, and EG is called a Jak.

s4.def: Naut. Short for jack-cross-tree1b.

q.qt: Though I could handle the brig's fore-royal easily, I found my hands full with this, especially as there were no jacks to the ship.
Jack,‥also a common term for the jack or cross-trees.
Rove through a block under the jack.
The jack at the fore-top-gallant mast-head.

s4.def: A vessel used in soap-making.

q.qt: They are poured off into vessels called ‘jacks’.

s4.def: A post-chaise. slang or colloq.

q.qt: We travelled upon jacks, which is the pleasantest conveyance in the world both for its sociability and the little fatigue which attends it.
Jack, a post-chaise.

s4.def: A schooner-rigged vessel used in the Newfoundland fisheries. Also jack boat.

cit.bibMain: Rep. U.S. Comm. Fish & Fisheries 1887 App. VI.529

q.qt: The jack varies from 5 to 15 tons; is schooner-rigged, carrying three sails as a rule.
The gashers were dashing in and out among the punts and jacks (stoutly built two-stickers larger than gashers).
A little jack (much the same in rig as our North Sea smacks).
Bill had a nice little jack (small fishing schooner, in this case with outriggers on the quarters instead of booms).
A typical Newfoundland jack seen in the cruise to the Bras D'Or Lakes.
Jack boats.‥ Bateaux ‘Jack’.

The ‘jack schooners’ or ‘jack boats’ (so-called in Cape Breton), or ‘two-spar boats’ (as they are known in Newfoundland) were 40′ to 50′ from stemhead to taffrail. They were gaff-rigged on both masts and they usually carried a longish bowsprit.
The sons of men who had built windjammers were confined to building trap skiffs and jack boats.

s4.ch_subject: Manufacturing and Industry/Commercial Fishing|Sport and Leisure/Hunting, Fishing, and Shooting/Hunting
s4.def: A portable cresset or fire-basket used in hunting or fishing at night. U.S.

q.qt: Standing with my eyes below the level of the flaming jack.

s4.def: A tablet of heroin. slang.

q.qt: Jack, heroin tablet.
He's been cranking up on horse sc. heroin. His last jack is wearing off, and he's grovelling on the floor for another pill.

s2.header: In names of animals. (Chiefly as an abbreviation of the fuller names treated under 4)

s4.def: Applied to the male of various animals, chiefly in comb.: see 4; also simply:

s6.ch_subject: Sport and Leisure/Hunting, Fishing, and Shooting/Hawking and Falconry
s6.def: A male hawk, esp. merlin (= jack-merlin4a(b)).

q.qt: A Merlin, the male is called a Iack. The Castrill male a Iack.
The Female of all Birds of Prey is much larger, stronger, and more couragious than the Male; which is distinguished therefrom by some diminutive Name‥; that of the Merlin, Jack.

s6.def: (Short for jackass1.) A male ass, esp. one kept for breeding mules. U.S.

q.qt: I have two or three young Jacks‥and several she asses, that I would dispose of.
A gentleman‥took it into his head that it would be an immense public advantage to introduce a breed of mules, and accordingly imported three jacks to stock the neighbourhood.
He leisurely untied From head and neck the halter of the jack.

s4.def: Short for jack-rabbit

q.qt: The Doctor's experience with a jack rabbit was one of the most amusing of the hunt.‥ One day he wounded a big jack, and as he went to pick it up, it arose upon its hind legs.

s4.def: Name for various birds.

s6.def: Short for jackdaw, jack curlew4b, Cornish jack, the Cornish chough, jack snipe
As the second element in various names, as curlew-jackcurlew3, jumping-jackjumping2, whisky jack: see these words.

q.qt: Curlew jacks (whimbrels).
It may be said both of full snipe and jack that they afford not only the best, but the most legitimate kind of sport.

s6.def: Austral. A laughing jackass, a kookaburra. Cf. Jacko, Jacky1c.

q.qt: The bird is generally called only a Jackass, and this is becoming contracted into the simple abbreviation of Jack.
Jack came to the conclusion that it was, as tucker, a washout, and departed.
Hence such names for the kookaburra as laughing jackass, jack.

s4.def: Name of various fishes, etc.

s6.def: A young or small pike; also sometimes used generically as a name for the pike. (Pl. jack or jacks.)

q.qt: The pike as he ageth, receiueth diuerse names,‥from a pod to a iacke, from a iacke to a pickerell, from a pickerell to a pike.
Old great Pikes are very hard, tough, and ill to digest: young ones (called Jacks) are contrariwise too watrish and moist.
The Jack may come to swallow the Pike, as the Interest often eats out the Principal.
The Gentleman‥had the Pleasure of seeing the huge Jack, he had caught, served up for the first Dish.
A method which I have taken more pikes and jacks with, than any other way.
Jack, a young male pike, under a foot in length.
Jack may be caught in the river Roding.

s6.def: Also applied to several American fishes: as the pike-perch, Stizostedium vitreum; a scorpænoid fish, Sebastodes paucispinis; several carangoid fishes, esp. Caranx pisquetos and Seriola carolinensis; and the pampano, Trachynotus carolinus. (Cent. Dict.)

q.qt: Other game fishes of Florida are the ‘jack’, or crevallé, also called carvalho.

s6.def: With defining word. buffalo-jack, the Caranx pisquetos (also called simply jack: see 31b). five-fingered jack: popular name in U.S. for a starfish. goggle-eyed jack: see goggler2hickory-jack: the Caranx pisquetos or one of several other carangoid fishes (see 31b);the hickory-shad, Pomolobus mediocris.
poor Jack (also dry or dried Jack)poor Jackdry Jackdried Jack, a name for dried hake; also called Poor John.

q.qt: This week arrived here 9 English ships, whereof 4 with Pilchards, 4 with poor Jack, and one with Herrings.
They pay‥half a pound of dried Jack.
That sort of Cod that is caught near the Shore, and on the Coast of Newfoundland and dryed, is called Poor-Jack.
Lading, consisting of‥Dry Codfish, Dry Jack, Hogslard.
Sometimes Poor Jack and Onions are his Dish, And then he Saints all those that stink of fish.

s4.ch_subject: Sport and Leisure/Hunting, Fishing, and Shooting/Angling
s4.def: A kind of worm used as bait by anglers. Obs.

q.qt: Crabtree-worm, or Jack.

s4.def: In names of plants. pop. or colloq.

s6.def: A variety of polyanthus: ‘one of the forms of the so-called “hose-in-hose” polyanthus, having the calyx more or less coloured, and partly assuming the character of the corolla’ (Britten and Holland Plant-n.1879). Cf. Jack-in-the-box8b.
Name for a single carnation fraudulently sold as a choice variety.

q.qt: Jacks is the horticultural slang designation for single carnations, which are grown specially for the trading hawker‥and sold to the unsuspicious as best named varieties.
He has been victimised by the sharp dealers in single Carnations, usually called ‘Jacks’.

s4.def: As the first element in a personal name used in a specific sense:

s6.ch_firstSource: New Dictionary of the Canting Crew

sub.def: a fool.

q.qt: Jack-adams, a Fool.
That from a Quaker in the other World, I should be metamorphos'd into a Jack Adams in the Lower one.
Jack Adams, a stubborn fool.

s6.ch_lemma: before one can say Jack Robinson
s6.def: before one can say Jack Robinson: in a very short time, very quickly or suddenly. (See also Jack Ketch)

q.qt: I'd do it as soon as say Jack Robinson.
Before I could say ‘Jack Robinson’.
The white and flying cloud of noon, that is gone before one can say ‘Jack Robinson’.
Before you could say Jack Robinson our dogies‥were running in half a dozen different directions.
It'll be all over College before you can say Jack Robinson.
That picture will appear at Christies before you can say Jack Robinson, though there is no necessity whatever for such a sale.

s6.ch_subject: Sport and Leisure/Hunting, Fishing, and Shooting/Angling

sub.def: = Jock ScottJock1a.

q.qt: ‘There are some grilse come up. What do you think would be a good fly to use?’‥‘I should put on a small Jack Scott.’
He‥got out his case of fishing-flies, and gallantly presented Betsy and me with‥a ‘Jack Scott’‥to make hat-pins.

sub.etym: the name of a noted African-American boxer, whose nickname was ‘The Big Smoke’
sub.def: = Black Maria3.

q.qt: The German ‘Jack Johnson’ siege-guns.
The gigantic projectile which on bursting makes the black smoke called ‘Jack Johnson’.
For high or low velocity German shells, as substitutes for ‘marmite’, the British soldier came out with ‘coalbox’, ‘Black Maria’, ‘Jack Johnson’, ‘heavy stuff’.
The German heavy batteries‥dropped ‘Jack Johnsons’ among us.

sub.def: rhyming slang for ‘alone’; usu. in phr. on one's Jack Jones: on one's own; alone. Cf. sense 2e.

q.qt: Jack Jones, alone.
A good night's kip all alone.‥ All on your Jack Jones.
You're on your jack jones again. What do you do?
You're on your Jack Jones. Ben's deserted you.

div.def: Combinations denoting things, etc. (chiefly mechanical or other contrivances), or connected with those senses of the simple word which denote things. See also jack-chain, etc.

def.subDef: in Brewing, a vessel with a perforated bottom for straining the wort from the hops (also called hop-back: see hop2);
‘a tank which receives the cooled wort in a vinegar-factory’ (Knight).

q.qt: The jack-back‥is placed something lower than the under-backs, and has a communication with them all; and out of this back the wort is pumped into the coppers.
The jack-back, which receives the wort after it has been boiled with the hops.
The liquor is pumped‥into a large reservoir, called a jack-back, in which it is allowed to remain until all the yest has collected on the surface.

sub.def: a donkey-engine.

q.qt: Jack Engine (N.), the engine for raising men, débris, &c. in a sinking pit.

sub.def: (see quots.).

q.qt: A Jack-file, is a broad File somewhat thin on both edges, and stronger in the middle.
Jack-File, a broad File: with this Jack-Wheels have their Teeth cut in them.

def.subDef: fishing for jack (sense 31);
U.S. fishing at night by means of a jack or cresset.

q.qt: Jack Tackle of every description‥Tackle for bottom and jack fishing.

sub.def: the fly-wheel of a roasting-jack.

q.qt: She‥set her tongue a going with the fury of a Jack-flyer.

sub.def: a portable rock-drill worked by compressed air.

q.qt: A battery of about 45 jackhammers‥drilled two lines of holes.
While this may be possible with machine drills in development faces, it is difficult at the moment to see how such appliances could be used with mobile jackhammers in stoping.
A specially-designed percussion drill similar to a jack-hammer.
He works a ship and has about the delicacy of a jackhammer.

sub.ch_firstSource: Transactions of the Society of Arts
sub.def: ‘a form of lift-pump for mines and deep borings, in which the delivery-pipe is secured to the cylinder by a goose-neck’ (E. H. Knight Pract. Dict. Mech.).

q.qt: In the manner of (what is called) a Jack Head Pump.

sub.ch_subject: Sport and Leisure/Hunting, Fishing, and Shooting/Hunting
sub.def: hunting by means of a jack-light (sense 26).

q.qt: I went out after dark to kill a deer by the unsportsmanlike method of jack-hunting.

def.subDef: ‘one with wooden steps and side ropes’ (Knight): = Jacob's ladder2;
= jack-chain2.

q.qt: From the rear end of the mill‥a ‘jack ladder’ is constructed of heavy timber.
An endless spiked conveyor known as a jack ladder.

sub.ch_subject: Sport and Leisure/Hunting, Fishing, and Shooting/Hunting

def.subDef: a Davy-lamp with a glass cylinder outside the gauze (Gresley Gloss.1883);
U.S. = sense 26.

q.qt: Occasionally a caribou is killed at night by the light of a jack-lamp while seeking the grass growing in some boatable stream.

sub.ch_subject: Sport and Leisure/Hunting, Fishing, and Shooting/Hunting

def.subDef: = sense 26;
= Jack-o'-lantern3.

q.qt: I have stood motionless on a flat rock‥amid the rushing water, with poised three-pronged spear behind a jack-lantern, waiting for a sturgeon to come there.

sub.def: a maker of jacks, i.e. (usually) of roasting-jacks.

q.qt: The humble petition of the colliers, cooks, cook-maids, blacksmiths, jack-makers, brasiers, and others.

sub.def: a belaying-pin.

q.qt: Jack-pins, a name applied to the fiferail pins.

sub.def: ‘a shallow pit-shaft in a mine communicating with an overcast, or at a fault’ (Gresley Gloss.1883).
a single-pronged plug for use with a jack (sense 15d).

q.qt: Jack plugs.
Jack and Jack plug, a socket with two or more contacts‥into which a jack plug with corresponding contacts can be inserted.

def.subDef: in draw-poker, a pot or pool that has to accumulate until one of the players can open the betting with a pair of jacks or better; hence fig.; (also) any large prize, as from a lottery or a gambling machine; often, a prize that accumulates until it is won; to hit the jack-pot: to win such a prize; to have an extraordinary stroke of luck,
(see quot. 1914).

q.qt: Poker-playing is not to be learned in one evening, and Jack Pots are often a snake in the grass.
Old Bill the warden just lays back until there is a good jack-pot of trout in hand, and then he makes a bold bluff and walks off with it.
They call this sc. growing poker pool a Jack Pot.
What was written of‥was a jack-pot.
He suggested a round of jack-pots.
The jackpot was worth it, for Miller represented the accumulated prize as having risen to £21,160.
On the occasion of his getting into a ‘jack-pot’ (some trouble) he had hunted Nome after me for legal advice.
Jackpot, a dilemma; a difficult strait; a retribution; trouble; an arrest.
I‥have been rather interested to learn that the Governor did not show you any degree of gratitude for your work in organizing the jackpot.
The ‘Vick's Vaper’ had indeed hit the jack-pot.
We saw our first American audience-participation show. The prizes included a diamond wrist watch.‥ The jackpot was 1,250 dollars!
Those sort of weak good looks‥quite often hit the jackpot.
Canada House receives SOS messages from ‘distressed Canadians’, the official designation for those who get themselves into various jackpots.
There is always the chance that one or other number or artist will hit the jackpot.

Cabinet Ministers are hauled out in front of the cameras and asked increasingly impertinent leading questions. A week or two ago Mr. Butler copped one of these jackpots from Robert Mackenzie: did he, or did he not, want to be Prime Minister?
A jackpot may be opened by any player who holds a pair of jacks or a higher ranking hand.
Rolls-Royce landed a jack-pot order from the USA for the supply of aircraft engines.
It was nice to be fairly widely read.‥ It would be even nicer if one day she contrived to hit the jackpot.

sub.def: the pulley of a roasting-jack.

q.qt: Such Jack-pullies, and Weights‥Atoms, which our modern Wits have fancied for the Springs of his Motion.

sub.def: a winch or windlass turned directly by handles.

q.qt: Sinking with Jack Rowl, or by Mens winding up the Rowl.
This was done by the aid of a ‘jack roll’, which is like the windlass over a common well.

sub.def: (see quots.); so jack-roll v. trans., jack-rolling.

q.qt: The ‘jack roller’,‥the man who robs his fellows, while they are drunk or asleep.
‘Jack rolling’ may be anything from picking a man's pocket in a crowd to robbing him while he is drunk or asleep.
Jack rollin' th' workstiffs was like takin' candy from th' kids.
I was in a predicament, for I had no money, and you can't enjoy life without dough. My buddy, being an old ‘jack-roller’, suggested ‘jack-rolling’ as a way out of the delima sic.
Thieves who specialize‥on lumberjacks or other seasonal workers who get paid off in a lump sum at the end of the season are called jack rollers.

sub.def: = jack-frame2.

q.qt: The ‘Jack roving-frame’ in which the revolving can contained a bobbin whereon the roving was wound as fast as made.

sub.def: any of various kinds of auxiliary or intermediate shafts which are driven by another shaft or by a set of gears, esp. in locomotives and motor vehicles (see quots.).

q.qt: The jack shaft of the frame makes 298 revolutions per minute.
The electric motor‥with jack-shaft and friction drive.
The jack shaft‥is a shaft passing across the car, and bearing on its ends the sprockets by which the wheels are driven.
The object of the differential is to enable either jack shaft to rotate at a different speed to the other‥whilst transmitting the drive.
The jackshaft is used for ratio purposes and also to break up long center distances.
Jackshafts. Location.—Either between head and line shafts, or between line- and countershafts.
Jack shaft, an intermediate shaft used in locomotives having collective drive; the jack shaft is geared to the motor shaft and carries cranks which drive the coupling rods on the driving wheels.

The final drive is through reduction gearing to a jackshaft which is fitted with pressed-on balanced cranks; thence the drive is by rods to the crankpins of the middle coupled wheels of the Diesel locomotive.
Jackshaft, a shaft with cranks at each end mounted across the frames for driving the road wheels through connecting rods.
A countershaft, especially when used as an auxiliary shaft between two other shafts, is termed a jack shaft.

sub.def: each of a series of thin metal plates suspended from the front ends of the jacks in a stocking-frame or knitting-machine (see 15a), and serving, in conjunction with the lead-sinkers, to form loops upon the thread.

q.qt: The jack sinkers falling successively from the loops on every alternate needle.

sub.def: = sense 15d.

q.qt: Modern amplifiers are often equipped with a jack socket wired to accommodate stereo headphones.
A suitable circuit for a miniature 2·5 mm. or 3·5mm. switched jack socket is given in Fig. 4, and this causes the speaker to be silenced when the jack plug is inserted.

sub.def: a workman who operates a jack in spinning (see 15c).
a long towel with the ends sewed together, suspended from a roller.

q.qt: The carrying-roller‥and the receiving-rollers‥are connected by a piece of linen, woollen, or hair-cloth, in the manner of a jack-towel, sewed round them.
A clean jack towel behind the door.

div.def: In some uses jack has a diminutive force or meaning, denoting things which are smaller or slighter than the normal ones. (See also 18–22, 303133b4b and jack)

sub.def: ‘an arch whose thickness is only of one brick’ (Gwilt Archit.184276).

q.qt: The windows are capped with jack-arches of red brick.

sub.def: (see quot. 1794).

q.qt: Jack-block, a small block seized to the topgallantmast-head, for sending the topgallant-yards up and down.

sub.def: the jack at bowls; = sense 18.

q.qt: He had not Strength‥to throw the Jack-Bowl half over the Green.
In shape and size like a jack-bowl, used on a bowling-green.

sub.def: see quot. 1867.

q.qt: The quarter boom-irons off her lower yards; her jack-cross-trees sent down.
Jack cross-trees, single iron cross-trees at the head of long top-gallant masts, to support royal and skysail masts.

sub.def: = jack-timber

q.qt: Which fill up with small and Jack Rafters at Pleasure.
It will be noticed that these rafters which are called jack-rafters decrease gradually in length.

sub.def: = jack-timber

q.qt: In the construction of groins,‥the ribs that are shorter than the whole width are termed Jack-ribs.

sub.def: one shorter than the full length.

q.qt: Jack Timber, a timber shorter than the whole length of other pieces in the same range.

div.def: Prefixed to another noun denoting a person, a thing personified, a trade, or a quality, so as to form a quasi-proper name or nickname, often applied familiarly or contemptuously.

sub.def: (a blunt fellow).

q.qt: He was at once a Jack Blunt and equal to a trick.

sub.def: (the ‘Boots’ at an inn).

q.qt: Six-pence to the chamber-maid, six-pence to the ostler, and six-pence to the jack-boot.
The Jack-boots of an Inn.

bibMain.w: Serm. Epist. S. Paule to Timothie & Titus

q.qt: We shall see iack-braggers, truce breakers, tratours full of crueltie & malice.

bibMain.w: Why come ye nat to Courte

q.qt: No man dare come to the speche Of this gentell Iacke breche.
Scuruy-Iack-dog-Priest: by gar, mee vill cut his eares.
Be Iack-fellow, sit still, or be covered.
The divell of the musition is he acquainted with but onlye Iacke fidler.
Go fro the wyndow, Iakke fool she sayde.
As well Iacke Iayler, as my Lord Judge.
I met some Jack Lords going into my Grove, but I think I have nettled them.
To keepe open hovse for euery Jack lovt.
Playe not Iack malapert 1477 Oriel Iakke mAlaperte that is to saye Beware of presumpcion.
Then will all your Elders thinke, you be with him Iack mate.
A Iackemedler, or busie-body, in euerie mans matter, ardelio.
He plays jack monkey at the altar, with his turns and half-turns.
He playeth the part of Iack Nitigo, as ye saying is, he seith but he wyll not se, or els that he seyeth a smal moate & letteth the great beame passe by.
Jack Presbyter can cry, God save the King.
By gar, I vill kill de Iack-Priest.
Euery Iacke-Slaue hath his belly full of Fighting.

sub.def: see drumb.

q.qt: With a broken pate or two, he was paid, and like iacke Drum, faire and orderly thrust out of dores.
They made no more adoe but gaue her Iack-drummes entertainement, thrusting her out of doores by the head and shoulders.
The Hostes being very willing to give the courteous entertainement of Jack Drum, commanded me very kindely to get me out of dores.

sub.def: (see quots.).

q.qt: The junior member of the Paymaster's Victualling staff is known as The Dusty Boy or Jack Dusty.
Jack Dusty, a ship's steward's assistant, i.e. any member of the supply branch below the rating of a petty officer.
In the Second World War, destroyers had a Jack Dusty, a supply assistant who kept ledgers listing all the stocks.

sub.def: frost or frosty weather personified.

q.qt: Jack Frost, however, put a veto on our morning's sport.
The blustering of old Boreas, and the frigid embrace of ‘Jack Frost’.

sub.def: a man of low birth or manners making pretensions to be a gentleman, an insolent fellow, an upstart; so Jack-gentlewoman (rare).

q.qt: What, Sir, do you think that it is fit for every Jack-Gentleman to speak thus to a Bishop?
They despised the Gentry at such a rate, that it was a common thing to call them Jack Gentleman.
Yet men there are (how strange are Love's decrees!) Whose palates even Jack-gentlewomen please.

sub.def: a non-Mormon on friendly terms with Mormons; (also) a nominal or backsliding Mormon.

q.qt: A certain Jack-mormon of Hancock county, we won't call him big-head, (but the Saints used to) is in the habit of shaving the hair off his forehead, in order to give it an intellectual appearance.
Jack Mormons, and sympathizers abroad may croak and groan over the poor Mormons.
In our country we have a genus homo called ‘Jack-Mormon’,‥a class of individuals who do not belong to the Mormon church,‥yet who are ever found doing the bidding of Mormon priests.
The number of backsliding ‘jack-Mormons’ is increasing.

sub.def: ‘a term of reproach for a sneak or a sloven’ (Davies).

q.qt: The idea of equality or inequality‥doesn't enter their heads till it's put there by Jack Nastys or fine ladies' maids.

sub.def: the northwest wind.

q.qt: We experienced‥uncommonly severe jack northwesters.

sub.def: a saucy or impudent fellow.

q.qt: Jack savce‥thov lovt, thov hoddie peake.
His reputation is as arrant a villaine and a Iacke sawce, as euer his blacke shoo trodd vpon Gods ground.
Why how now, Jack-sauce? why, how now, Presumption?

sub.def: (see quots.).

q.qt: This lad sc. an officer cadet‥was already rather a favourite, being of the breezy type, which sailors call a ‘Jack-shilloo’.
Jack Shalloo, a braggart according to its old naval meaning. Nowadays it is applied to a happy-go-lucky, careless officer and hence a slack ship is called a Jack Shalloo ship.
Jack Shalloo, naval officer whose aim in life is to be popular with the men. A corruption of John Chellew, an officer who earned himself the title Popularity Jack.

sub.def: a little fellow, a dwarf.

q.qt: Hard you euer such a counsell of such a Iacke sprot?
Jack-sprat, a Dwarf, or very little Fellow, a Hop-on-my-thumb.
[Nursery Rime, Jack Sprat could eat no fat, His wife could eat no lean.]

sub.def: a meddlesome or interfering person, a busybody.

bibMain.w: Serm. Epist. S. Paule to Timothie & Titus

q.qt: Howe many iacke sticklers are there nowe adayes‥which‥will needes shewe them selues to be somwhat by mouing troubles?
A prying medler [busie-body, jack-stickler] crouds in and intrudeth‥where it nothing concernes him.

sub.def: (see quots.).

q.qt: Jack Strop, a new recruit who tries to pass himself off as an old hand.
Jack Strop, the Mess Deck's sobriquet for a conceited, opinionated sort of man.

div.def: Substantive phrases with specific senses. See also Jack-a-Lent, Jack-in-the-box, Jack-in-the-green, Jack-o'-lantern

sub.def: a gallant, a ladies' man.

q.qt: The Mayor‥was a pleasant man, and Jack among the maids.

sub.def: (see quots.).

q.qt: When there was neede of my seruice‥I was seldome or neuer wanting; I was Iacke at a pinch.
Jack at a Pinch, a poor Hackney Parson.
Miss Coon‥knows that the Major took her to wife ‘Jack at a pinch’—seein' he couldent get such as he wanted, he took such as he could get.

sub.def: a servile attendant.

q.qt: As if‥the man were not to bee made any more account of than Iack hold my staffe, by these Rabbies.
Madam, in plain English I am made a John A-Nokes of, Jack-hold-my-staff,‥to give Leander time to marry your Daughter.

sub.ch_firstSource: New Dictionary of the Canting Crew
sub.def: ‘a consequential petty official’ (Davies); also attrib. (cf. Jack out of office).

q.qt: Jack in an Office, of one that behaves himself Imperiously in it.
I hate a Jack-in-office martinet.
A Jack-in-office, sir, and a very insolent fellow.
The clerks‥gave this young officer‥as much trouble as Jacks-in-office possibly can.

sub.def: a type of warning beacon (see quot. 1867).

q.qt: Jack in the basket, a sort of wooden cap or basket on the top of a pole, to mark a sand-bank or hidden danger.
How comfortingly the cocoa boiled on an even keel at dawn with Jack-in-the-basket in sight!
Jack-in-the-Basket. A beacon. The Moose River was well buoyed, and the many shoals were marked with high poles surmounted with long wicker baskets, or broom heads of willows.

sub.def: a rendering of Dutch Hans-in-kelder (see Hans), an unborn child.

q.qt: When his companions drank to the Hans en kelderr, or Jack in the low cellar, he could not help displaying an extraordinary complacence of countenance.

sub.def: (see quot. 1873).

q.qt: Jack-in-the-water.
The lads, who act as jacks-in-the-water, were busy feeling in the mud for the fish that had fallen over board.
Jack-in-the-water, an attendant at the watermen's stairs on the river and sea-port towns, who does not mind wetting his feet for a customer's convenience, in consideration of a douceur.

sub.def: a man who can turn his hand to any kind (or to many kinds) of work or business; also rarely Jack of all work(s)Jack of all worksJack of all work.

q.qt: Some broken Cittizen, who hath plaid Iack of all trades.
Thus Jack-of-all-trades hath devoutly showne The twelve Apostles on a Cherry-stone.
Your Writings are like a Jack of all Trades Shop, they have Variety, but nothing of value.
Jack at all trades, is seldom good at any.
Being a complete Jack of all trades, from the Carpenter to the Shepherd nothing comes strange to him.
My Jack of all works, who, by the by, is a universal gallant.
It would be unfair to say of Lord Brougham that he was ‘Jack of all trades and master of none’.

sub.subVfSect: also Jack on both sides, Jack o' both sides
sub.def: a person who sides first with one party and then with the other, a trimmer.

q.qt: A Godly and necessary Admonition concernyng Neutres, such as deserve the grosse name of Iacke of both sydes.
Claw-backes and Pickethanks: Jackes of bothe sides.
That he hath won this universal good will by the vice of playing Jack of both sides.
That he was a papist, a jack o' both sides.
‘Are you ready, gentlemen?’ said this Jack-o'-both-sides.

sub.def: name of some dish, ‘probably a pie that had been cooked more than once’ (Skeat).

q.qt: Many a Iakke of Douere hastow soold That hath been twies hoot and twies coold.

sub.def: a figure of a man made of straw (cf. jack-straw1).

q.qt: I‥would be marryed sooner to a Monkey, Or to a Jack of Straw, then such a Juggler.

sub.subVfSect: also Jack of the clock-house, Jackaclock quot. 1689
sub.def: = sense 6; also transf. applied to a person (see quots.)

q.qt: For mendinge the chymes‥and jake of the clockehouse.
While I stand fooling heere his iacke of the clocke.
A Man, like that which we call Jack of the Clock-house, striking as it were, the hour of that fulness of time.
A new bell made for the Jackaclock at Gosford Gate.

sub.def: ‘a man on board a United States man-of-war appointed to assist the paymaster's yeoman in serving out provisions and other stores’ (Cent. Dict.).

q.qt: Forward, on the gun-deck, the Paymaster's Steward, and his assistant, the Jack of the Dust, were serving out small stores.
He was doing duty at the time as paymaster's yeoman, or ‘Jack of the Dust’.

sub.def: (see quot. 1826).

q.qt: Formerly a pleasant character dressed out with ribands and flowers, figured in village May-games under the name of Jack-o'-the-Green‥. A Jack-o'-the-Green always carried a long walking stick with floral wreaths.

sub.def: a person turned out of his former place; a homeless person, a vagrant.

q.qt: At his returne he found the Towne taken, and himselfe jack-out-of-doores Fr. sa place saisie.
Not altogether Iack out of doores, and yet no gentleman.

sub.def: a person who has been dismissed from his office; one whose ‘occupation is gone’ (also rarely †Jack out of service)

q.qt: Gods good worde must weere the papyre, and be iack out of seruyce from other men.
Doth not this ceremony make Christ Iacke out of office?

bibMain.w: Serm. Epist. S. Paule to Timothie & Titus

q.qt: They challenge such a power to them selues, that Iesus Christe is iacke out of office with them.
For me nothing remaines: But long I will not be Iack out of Office.

tr.a: F. G. de Quevedo y Villegas

q.qt: We should be but so many Jacks out of Office.

sub.def: a will-o'-the-wisp; transf. a giddy or flighty person.

q.qt: If she had been a Jack-o'-wisp, in her young days‥would Lady Mary have chosen her?

sub.ch_subject: Crafts and Trades/Coins and Banknotes|Sciences/Mathematics|Sport and Leisure/Games

def.subDef: Sc. a kind of game (see quot. 1825); transf. a lively run round (quot. 1894);
rhyming slang for ‘five’; (also) a five-pound note.

q.qt: Jack's alive, a kind of sport. A piece of lighted paper or match is handed round a circle, he who takes hold of it saying, ‘Jack's alive, he'se no die in my hand’. He, in whose hand it dies or is extinguished, forfeits a wad.
He gave her a mare ‘Jack's alive’ round the field.
Jacks Alive, the number 5, especially at House.
Jack's Alive, a five-pound note.

sub.def: a kind of acrid green tea formerly used in the Australian bush.

q.qt: Another notorious ration tea of the bush is called ‘Jack the painter’. This is a very green tea indeed.
The billy wins, and ‘Jack the Painter’ tea Steams on the hob, from aught like fragrance free.
Jack the painter‥from the stain left round the drinker's mouth or in the billy (at least, that is the approved explanation).

sub.def: popular name for a murderer of women in London in 1888, who mutilated the bodies of his victims; also used allusively.

q.qt: A Jack the Ripper outrage at Moscow.
Now we know 'oo Jack the Ripper was!
If only the officer would let him have a whack at her over the open sights, he'd do the Jack-the-ripper act on her in half a tick.
I expected to see a bashi-bazook or a revolutionary Jack the Ripper, but he was neither.
I had to obtain a Home Office permit. And in case you still think I'm Jack the Ripper, here it is.
There's a lousy fog.‥ It's a Jack the Ripper's paradise.

div.def: In names of animals (sometimes signifying male, sometimes small, half-sized).
Denoting the male of certain animals. See also jackass

q.qt: That extreme ‘facial development’, which imparts it seems to the countenance of several of her ladyship's friends, the character of jack-apes.
If‥Trout are well on the feed they will take the male or ‘Jack’ flies readily.
Swearing it was the largest Jack Hare he ever saw.

div.def: esp. of falcons.

q.qt: Of Merlins there are both male and female: the male is called the Iack-Merlin.

div.def: See also jackdaw, jack-rabbit, jack snipe

sub.ch_subject: Sport and Leisure/Hunting, Fishing, and Shooting/Hunting
sub.def: a name for Picathartes gymnocephalus, a West African corvine bird.

q.qt: One of the chief features of Free Town are the jack crows.

sub.def: name for two small species of curlew: the Whimbrel, Numenius phæopus;the N. hudsonicus of North America.

q.qt: The Whimbrel has‥in some parts‥obtained the name of Jack Curlew, from a supposition that it is the male of that bird.
Numenius hudsonicus (Of Hudson's Bay), Hudsonian Curlew, Jack Curlew.

sub.def: a name for the pike; also for Caranx pisquetos and other carangoid fishes (see 31).

q.qt: A worthy object‥which might well detain you from roach and jack-fish.

sub.def: a name for the long-tailed titmouse, also called bottle-tit, from the shape of its nest.

q.qt: British Long-tailed Titmouse‥Jack in a bottle.

sub.ch_firstSource: Rep. Fisheries Div., Dept. Commerce & Agric. (Austral.)
sub.def: any of several game fishes of the genera Trachurus and Caranx (family Carangidae).

bibMain.w: Rep. Fisheries Div., Dept. Commerce & Agric. Austral.

q.qt: The Division‥was instrumental in having the species renamed jack mackerel.
The original jack mackerel is Trachurus symmetricus of California, but when in 1950, Australia began to export T. novaezelandiae as a food-fish, that species was officially designated jack mackerel.
The Peruvian jack mackerel (Trachurus murphyl) is a schooling, pelagic species commonly found along the west coast of South America and in recent years in the Central South Pacific.
Japanese jack mackerel (Trachurus japonicus)‥is similar to African jack mackerel (Caranx hippos).

sub.def: a small terrier named after John Russell (17951883), the so-called ‘sporting parson’.

q.qt: In another decade or so the neglected Sealy Ham Terrier,‥and the almost forgotten Jack Russell strain, may have claimed a due recompense for their long neglect.
‘I have kept the Jack Russell type of terrier for nearly twenty years,’ says Mr. Reginald Bates, ‘and have used them for fox and badger digging.’
Perhaps the most popular is the ‘Jack Russell’ which‥may now be considered a breed.

Jack Russell terrier. A small working terrier, named (for no very sound reason) after a West Country parson sc. the Rev. John Russell of Devonshire who, a century ago, was renowned for his working terriers. Any small Hunt terrier may be called a Jack Russell.‥ There is no distinct type and the breed is not recognised by the Kennel Club.
A little tubby man‥with‥the look of an overfed Jack Russell terrier.

sub.def: a large freshwater fish, Stizostedion vitreum, also called walleyed pike.

q.qt: The species commonly known as Susquehanna salmon, pike, perch, jack salmon‥shall henceforth not be taken‥during their spawning time.
We always hope‥to catch a few jack salmon.

sub.def: a name for the Goosander, Mergus merganser (see quot. 1885).

q.qt: Goosander,‥ From its saw-like bill this bird is called Sawbill (Stirling).‥Sawneb (Aberdeen). Jacksaw.

sub.def: a northern dialect name for the stickleback

q.qt: I went into the grounds where I had often sported, read, talked, searched for birds' nests, and caught jack-sharps.
He mun larn to tak' care on himsel' th' next time he marlocks among th' Jacksharps.

A boy of ten was attempting to catch jacksharps when he fell from the embankment into the stream.‥ (South-country readers will be interested to learn that jacksharps are the little fishes known to them as sticklebacks or tittlebats.)
There are numerous local names for this fish sc. the three-spined stickleback, such as Jack Sharp, Prickleback, etc..
The worker pursuing his weekend hobby of angling may find round a pond cockies or jacksharps, ‘sticklebacks’ to the uninitiated.

sub.def: a large species of wasp found in the West Indies.

q.qt: I‥should make my self full amends of Jack Spaniard.
The jack-spaniard may be called the wasp of the West Indies; it is twice as large as a British wasp.
The Jack-spaniard may be called the wasp of the West Indies, it is twice as large as a British wasp.
Sitting on the sandy turf, defiant of galliwasps and jack-spaniards.
A hornet, called by the packers a ‘Jack-Spaniard’,‥builds a circular paper nest.
Polistes Latreille. Four species of this genus were collected in Trinidad. P. canadensis (L.). Typical form. ‘Jack Spaniard’. Common throughout all settled areas.
You could as well discover the particular jack-spaniard that stung you a week ago.

div.def: In popular names of plants. Sometimes with the sense ‘Dwarf, undersized’. See also Jack-in-the-box8, Jack-in-the-green2.

q.qt: The land in this distance is mostly clothed with jack bushes and tall woods.

sub.def: a North American species of oak (Quercus nigra); also called black jack (cf. black jack3).

q.qt: Jack Oaks and other Scrub Wood.
The timber in the bottoms‥is a kind of Jack oak and very low Cotton Wood.
The post-oak and Jack-oak are considered in Texas as every man's property.
The ‘jack oak hills’ have been fenced.

sub.def: local name in Ireland for Goose-grass or Clivers (Britten & Holland, Appendix).
a sub-tropical, climbing, leguminous plant of the genus Canavalia, esp. C. ensiformis.

q.qt: He sat upon the cabin porch beneath the yellow gourds an the purple blooms of the Jack-bean.
Jack Bean. Chickasaw Lima Bean.‥ The young beans (about 4 to 6 in. long) are sometimes used like Scarlet Runners; the ripe seeds are said to be used as a substitute for coffee.

sub.def: the Hedge-garlic, Sisymbrium Alliaria; also locally applied to Lychnis diurna, Tragopogon pratensis, and Linaria minor (Br. & Holl.).

q.qt: Alliaria,‥Iak of the hedge.
In Englishe Sauce alone, and Iacke by the hedge.
Jack by the Hedge, or Sauce Alone‥was a favourite condiment.

sub.def: Ornithogalum umbellatum and Tragopogon pratensis (the latter also called simply go-to-bed-at-noon (see go-to-bed-at-noongo3)).

q.qt: The leaves and stems are often the only portions of the plant sc. Yellow Goat's Beard to attract the eye of the wanderer, for the flower is closed by mid-day. Several of its country names refer to this peculiarity, as Noontide, and Jack-go-to-bed-at-noon.
The Goat's Beard opens its blossoms at daybreak and closes them before noon, except in cloudy weather, hence its old country name of ‘Noon-flower’ and ‘Jack-go-to-bed-at-noon’.
How punctual they!‥ As testifies ‘Jack-go-to-bed-at-noon’.

def.subDef: local name for Hedge-garlic;
= Jack-in-the-green1.

q.qt: A more extraordinary figure is sometimes in company, whom they call Jack-in-the-Bush; as the name indicates, nothing but bush is to be seen, except the feet which dance under it. The man stands in a frame-work which is supported upon his shoulders, and is completely covered with the boughs of a thick and short-branched shrub.
He sc. the sawyer said wild garlic, called Jack-in-the-Bush, is a famous pot herb.

sub.def: = jack-by-the-hedge, the hedge-garlic, Alliaria petiolata.

q.qt: Jack-in-the-hedge, Lychnis diurna.
Young spring flowers—primroses, violets, jack-in-the-hedge, stitchwort—in palest blossom starred the banks.
The many and various scents of the flowers, Cuckoo-pint, cow-parsley and jack-in-the-hedge.

sub.def: a North American araceous plant, Arisæma triphyllum, so called from the appearance of the upright spadix partly surmounted by the enclosing spathe.

q.qt: Fine specimens of Jack-in-the pulpit, and the moccassin-flower.
It would have been like looking at a jack-in-the-pulpit.
Our well-known jack-in-the-pulpit, or Indian-turnip, with its purple-streaked canopy and sleek ‘preacher’ standing erect beneath it.
In these woods I made acquaintance with Jack-in-the-pulpits, or, as the English call them, ‘Lords and Ladies’.
A few of these, like Indian turnip or jack-in-the-pulpit, cowslip and milkweed, may be considered mildly inedible.
Soups were popular, some brewed with‥buffalo meat, berries, fat, and the roots of jack-in-the-pulpits.

sub.def: local name for Angelica sylvestris, Ægopodium Podagraria, and Lotus corniculatus (Br. & Holl.).

q.qt: Jack-jump-about, N'hants; king's fingers, Bucks.
Wild Angelica, Jack-Jump-About, Water Squirt and many more. A fairly common native wild flower found in damp places in woods and meadows with purplish stems and umbels.

sub.def: an old name for Stonecrop, Sedum acre; also called Creeping Jack.

q.qt: Stonecrop,‥wall Pepper, countrey Pepper, and Iacke of the butterie.

sub.def: any of several species of pine, esp. the Banksian pine, Pinus banksiana.

q.qt: This country is now grown up with scattering dwarf pines or, as the settlers call them, jack-pines.
The jack-pine grows low and twisted.
I‥looked up and saw jackpines in the moon.
I saw, moving majestically towards me and looming over the head of the crowd like a Douglas fir among jackpine, a prematurely grey giant about nine feet tall.
The range of the jack pine (P. banksiana), the most northern of eastern American pines, extends south from near the Arctic Circle to New York and Minnesota.

sub.etym: perhaps compare the expression Jack's the Lad, found in a nautical song (see quot. 1840) and in a number of other allusions in the 19th cent.
sub.def: colloq., a conspicuously self-assured, carefree, and often brash young man; a ‘chancer’.

q.qt: For if ever fellow took delight in swigging, gigging, kissing, drinking, fighting, Damme I'll be bold to say that Jack's the lad.
Jack's the lad.
I think to myself, now you're going to be a real Jack-the-lad with your generosity.
You're Jack the Lad. I've known a few performers in my time.
I was always Jack the Lad—the one everyone liked but nobody wanted to know.
Find somebody‥who‥just might be Jack the Lad.
The East End urchin Tony, later a Jack-the-lad and Jack-of-all-trades.

etymSect.etym: Frenchjaque, in Old French also jaques (1375 in Hatzfeld & Darmesteter), in Italiangiacco, Germanjacke, Dutchjak, Swedishjacka jacket. Ultimate origin uncertain, but apparently French: thought by some to be identical with the proper name Jacques, perhaps as originally worn by the peasantry. In sense 1 possibly ultimately of the same origin as Jack, but not derived from that word in English, being of common European currency. Sense 2, and still more 3, are doubtfully placed here; both may belong to Jack

s6.def: A short and close-fitting upper garment of men and women; a jacket. Obs.

q.qt: Unum iakke de rubio worstede.
Wommen‥with her hornes‥rydelid gownes, and rokettis, colers, lacis, iackes, pattokis, with her longe crakowis.

s6.def: esp. A coat of fence, a kind of sleeveless tunic or jacket, formerly worn by foot-soldiers and others, usually of leather quilted, and in later times often plated with iron; sometimes applied to a coat of mail. (See Meyrick in Archæol. XIX. 224.) arch.

q.qt: Þorȝ-out ys scheld & is habreioun, Plates, & iakke & ioupoun, þorȝ-out al it ȝot.
The kynge had on a iacke couered with blacke veluet, whiche sore chafed hym.
Quhar for i exort ȝou that ȝe change ȝour sperutual habitis‥in steil iakkis and in cotis of mailȝe to deffend ȝour bodeis.
On jacke with a brest of plate‥iijs. iiijd.
Through his golden plated Iacke he thrust into the side.
Like‥the yron plates of a iacke, one lying on an other.
The leather quilted Iacke in iourneying and in camping, for that it is fittest to be under his shirt of Male.
They had brought with them good Iackes of Male.
Persons‥arm'd with Blunderbuss's, Pistols,‥Jackcaps, Leather Doublets and Jacks.
Some had the black jack, or doublet, covered with small plates of iron of a lozenge shape.
The coats of livery, or ‘jacks’ as they were called, which the soldiers wore at Creçy.

s6.ch_firstSource: Newe Comedie of Jacob and Esau
s6.ch_lemma: to be on a person's jack
s6.def: Phr. to be on (a person's) jack: to lay blows on him, to attack him; to be on his back, be down upon him. Obs.

q.qt: If I wrought one stroke to day, lay me on the iacke.
That they‥should sticke to it like men, & laye it on the iacks of them.
So soone‥might the king of Nauar be sure that he would be vpon his iacke.
They shall not‥stirre and put out their heads, but we will be streight upon their iacks L. ab tergo.
All the Mariners are vpon the iacke of Ionas.

s4.def: A vessel for liquor (either for holding liquor, or for drinking from); orig. and usually of waxed leather coated outside with tar or pitch (= black jack1); a (leathern) jug or tankard. arch.‘A Iacke of leather to drinke in, because it somewhat resembles a iacke or coat of maile’ (Minsheu Ductor1617).

q.qt: Trene dishes doth wel, wodden spones go to wrack where stone is no laster, take tankarde and iacke.
Hanap ou tasse à boire, a tankard, a iacke.

bibMain.w: Dodsley's Sel. Coll. Old Eng. Plays

q.qt: To the buttery-hatch, to Thomas the butler for a jack of beer.
1 jack of leather to drink in.
Two Drinking Jacks of Leather, edged round with Silver.
And they each took a smack At the coal-black-Jack Till the fire burnt in their brain.
A large black leathern jack, which contained two double flagons of strong ale.
Water that I had in a tin jack.

s4.ch_firstSource: Manners and Household Expenses of England
s4.def: Name for some joint of mutton. Obs.

q.qt: Laid out in a brest and a jakke of motone, v. d.

div.def: Comb., as jack-maker; jack-capa leathern cap to protect the head.jack-coata jacket or jack.

Also a sarge jack coat, and a sarge paire of breeches.

A Jackcoat and old Leather Breeches.
Firemen to whom they give Jack-Caps of Leather, able to keep them from Hurt, if Brick or Timber, or any thing not of too great a Bulk, should fall upon them.

etymSect.etym: Portuguesejaca (in Garcia De Orta, 1563), Malayalamchakka. The earliest European representation of the word is chaqui in Friar Jordanus 1328 (Hakl. Soc. 1863,13): see Yule.

s4.def: The fruit of a tree (Artocarpus integrifolia) of the East Indies, resembling the bread-fruit, but larger and of coarser quality. Also the tree itself.

q.qt: Iacas are bigger‥and grow out of the bodie of the tree: they are of so many pleasant tastes, but hard to digest.
The Iacks or Giacks‥deserue description‥the Iacke is for bignesse comparable to a Pumpion.
This side is all covered with Trees of Cocoes, Jawks, and Mangoes.
Banka‥abounds in coco nuts, limes, nankas or jacks, fish, turtle, and ratans.
Of the Jack fruit‥two species occur in the Indian islands.‥ The Jack is highly nutritious.
Brazil is indebted to the intercourse of the Portuguese with the East Indies‥for the excellent fruits of the jaca, the mango, and the jambos.

bibMain.w: Polit. & Statist. Acct. Straits of Malacca

q.qt: In the valley grow various fruit-trees, such as‥the jack.
The jack, with broad glossy leaves and enormous yellow fruit.
The monstrous jáck that in its eccentric bulk contains a whole magazine of tastes and smells.
The native of the country is content with the fruit that is easily produced there and is already well known (in this case the durian, mango, sapodilla, mangosteen, jak, etc.).
The fruits of the Jaca, as large as a man's head, seem to grow directly from the trunk and boughs.

Jak or Jack Fruit (Artocarpus integrifolia) is a related species with enormous fruits which can weigh up to 70 lb. each. In spite of their very strong odour, they are relished especially in Asia and may be eaten cooked or raw.
There were also great numbers of a wild Jack-fruit tree (Artocarpus), which bore abundance of large reticulated fruit.
The shameless stranger‥issued from the saffron sunset, somewhere behind the spiky line of the mission jack fruit trees.
Doors, mostly of local jack-fruit tree wood, are still being carved by Swahili craftsmen.
It is said that he once had a vision in which Krishna asked him to carve his image from the wood of a certain jack-fruit tree.
The handle of his parang, which was made of the heartwood of a jack-fruit tree.
The cook having chosen to roast a jackfruit on a spit.
To dream about eating jack-fruit (nangka)‥is an indication of great trouble impending.
We have‥Jack fruit‥in plenty.
The Jack Fruits are ripening a little—they are extraordinary, with crocodile scales.
A Malay kampong stands‥half hidden by an assortment of fruit trees—durian, jack-fruit, mangosteen and rambutan.
Jack and saul timber, are frequently to be met with in the forests and jungles.
A sort of large Club-Moss putting forth of the Jack-Trees and Mango's.
The rich green foliage of mature plaintain and jak trees.
The jack-wood‥at first yellow, becomes on exposure to the air of the colour of mahogany.

Second edition, 1989; online version June 2012. <>; accessed . An entry for this word was first included in New English Dictionary, 1900.

etymSect.etym: Origin somewhat obscure; but most probably a specific application of Jack (sense 1b), said of and applied to things of smaller than the normal size; as if short for ‘jack-flag’, i.e. small flag (so called in contradistinction to the ensign): compare the various uses of jack for jack-bowl, jack-brick, jack-fish, etc.; also the naval use in jack = jack-cross-trees. Other conjectures have been offered, e.g. that the name is the FrenchJacques, James, and that the jack was so called from King James I, who introduced the original union flag; or, that the word is probably identical with jack, the leathern surcoat having been (it is suggested) sometimes emblazoned with the cross of St. George. But apparently neither of these conjectures covers the early use of the word.

s4.def: A ship's flag of smaller size than the ensign, used at sea as a signal, or as a mark of distinction; spec. the small flag which is flown from the jack-staff at the bow of a vessel (formerly at the sprit-sail topmast head), and by which the nationality of a ship is indicated, as in British jack, Dutch jack, French jack.In British use the jack has been since the 17th c. (except under the Commonwealth) a small sized ‘Union Flag’ of the period (Union Jack), which has also been, since 1707, inserted in the upper canton of the ensign; hence, the name ‘union jack’ is often improperly applied to the union flag itself, when this is not carried or used as a jack. Every maritime nation has a jack of its own; this is usually, either as in Great Britain, †the German Empire, Sweden, and the United States, the same as the canton of the ensign, or, as in France and the Netherlands, identical with the ensign, only smaller. (Prof. J. K. Laughton.)

q.qt: You are alsoe for this present service to keepe in yor Jack at yor Boultspritt end and yor pendant and yor Ordinance.
If ye cheife of ye squadron come by ye Lee and make a waft wth his Jack that then every shipp of his squadron beare undr his sterne and speake wth him.
That the Dutch did take her sc. the Royal Charles with a boat of nine Men‥and presently a man went up and struck her flag and Jacke.
A Ship carrying the Hambrough Colours, who upon our Commanding him on Board with a Gun, immediately put up a Holland Ensign, and a Flushing Jack.
All vessels whatsoever being in the King's service and wearing his colours, flag or Jack may have the same right done to them.
A sorry yacht, but bearing the English jack, in August 1671.
He knew her to be a Custome-house boat by her Jack or pendant.
This day was published their majesties proclamation‥prohibiting other than the kings ships to wear their majesties Jack, called the Union Jack.

All such Ships as have Commissions of Letters of Mart or Reprisals, shall, besides the Colours which may be worn by Merchants Ships, wear a Red Jack, with the Union Jack, described in a Canton of the upper Corner thereof next the Staff.
He entered into the Bay under French Jack and Pendent.
The Signal is to shew a white Jack at the Main Top-mast Head.

Jack, a sort of flag colour or colours displayed from a mast erected on the outer end of a ship's bowsprit. In the British navy the jack is‥a small union flag‥but in merchant-ships this union is bordered with a red field.
At day-light, an English jack was hoisted at the mast-head.
I had established a signal with L'Amiable, a Dutch Jack inverted, when I wanted a boat.
A Spanish two-decker‥hauled in her colours‥and waved an English Jack from her traffle.
The British Jack obtained a complete triumph.

In the United States naval service the jack is a blue flag with a white five-pointed star for each State in the Union. It is hoisted on a jack-staff at the bowsprit-cap when in port, and is also used as a signal for a pilot when shown at the fore.
The ‘Jack’ and the ensign still continue to be carried on staves at the extremities of the vessel.

q.qt: ‘Jack’ is a second native American cheese. It was first made in Monterey County, California, about a quarter of a century ago, and was then called ‘Monterey’ cheese.
Jack cheese is plentiful here and selling at about 14 cents.
Jack cheese was first made in Monterey County, Cal., about 35 years ago and was then called Monterey cheese.
With his sons he sc. David Jacks is credited with having developed a popular type of soft cheese now widely sold in the city markets as Monterey or Jack cheese.
Pepper Jack‥. Olympic Brand. Random Weight Chunks‥. 20¢.
Try one of their special alfalfa sprout, avocado and jack cheese open face sandwiches.
Serve this tasty blend with tortilla chips, shredded Jack cheese and sour cream.
The sandwich is finished with jalapeño jack cheese and slices of pickles.
The sandwich, with turkey, bacon and jack cheese, is fresh and simple, although on the dry side.

s4.def: trans.to jack up.

s6.def: To hoist with a jack (see Jack10).

q.qt: To ‘jack-up’ a seven-ton engine and replace it on the rails.
When we decided to give up the apple stand, I said it might make a nice little cabin. My husband Ralph jacked it up and put it on a flatbed wagon and tractored it up through the west orchard.
I enjoy reminiscing over early motoring days.‥ Jack up the back tyre to ensure easier starting.

s6.def: transf. and fig. To raise, increase; to force or bolster up. colloq. (orig. U.S.).

q.qt: The management thought it saw a chance to jack up rents, and made a sudden announcement of a raise.
She had jacked up the price on the table d'hôte ten francs.
At his first trial, Cho Bong-Am got only five years, but a second trial jacked this up to capital punishment.

s6.def: To arrange, organize, fix up; to put right, spruce up. N.Z.slang.

q.qt: Jack-up, a term meaning to achieve the apparently impossible or to bring out of chaos; to arrange, inveigle, wangle or bolster up (a) Any transport (b) any alibi (c) leave (d) ED pay—usually without the prior knowledge or consent of authority.

I've jacked up a hot snack for the end of the shoot.

s4.ch_subject: Sport and Leisure/Hunting, Fishing, and Shooting/Angling
s4.def: intr. To hunt or fish at night with a jack (see Jack26). U.S.

q.qt: Gad went out ‘jacking’ with him, and jumped right over the bow of the boat to catch a deer.

s4.def: dial. or colloq.to jack up:

def.subDef: To do for, ruin.
To throw up, give up, abandon. (Cf. chuck2b) Also simply to jack (rare).

q.qt: Jacked-up, ruined, done for.
The Liberal canvassers‥became dissatisfied and threatened to ‘Jack up’ their books.

About 16 per cent ‘jack it up’ and go back to the slough and mire.

s6.def: absol. or intr. To give up suddenly or promptly.

q.qt: To jack-up is to leave off doing anything suddenly.

As a man, a gentleman, and a squatter, I ‘jacked up’ at the cookery.

s4.def: Slang phr. to jack in: to abandon, leave, give up, stop. Freq. in phr. to jack it in.

q.qt: ‘What's your ol' woman do to you, Charlie?’ ‘Jacked me in for a civvy. I got home; no one there, no furniture, nothing.’
There was only fifteen of us on the hunger strike, I suppose the others must have got hungrey anyway they jacked it in.
I ain't goin' to jack it all in now for Chris or anyone.

s4.def: to jack off (intr.): to go away, depart;to masturbate. slang.

He plummets from the eyeless lighthouse, kissing and jacking off in face of the black mirror.

Entry.vfSectLoose: Forms: 16jaccal(l, jacal, jakhal, jackalle, chacall, (jagale, jacol, joecaul), 16–17jack-call, 16–18jackall, chacal, (17shackal(l, siacalle, 18shakal), 16–jackal.

etymSect.etym: Corruption of Turkishchakāl, Persianshagāl, or shaghāl, cognate with Sanskrits'rgāla, ç'rgāla jackal. Through Turkish also, Frenchchacal (formerly also in English), whence Portuguesechacal, Italiansciacal, German (Danish, Swedish) schakal. The Dutchjakhals was probably English: compare quot. 16941. The English word was formerly (as still in some dialects) stressed on the second syllable; the current form, and the obsolete Jack-call, show association with the proper name Jack, and names of animals containing it.

s4.def: An animal of the dog kind, about the size of a fox; one of various species of Canis, as C. aureus or C. anthus, inhabiting Asia and Africa, hunting in packs by night with wailing cries, and feeding on dead carcases and small animals; formerly supposed to go before the lion and hunt up his prey for him, hence termed ‘the lion's provider’.Described by Topsell, 1607 p. 439 as ‘the second kind of hyæna’.

q.qt: About Scanderone there are many ravenous beasts about the bignesse of a Foxe, commonly called there Jackalles.
Iaccalls‥do lurke in the obscure vaults.
A kind of beast little bigger then a Foxe‥vulgarly called Jagale, used to‥scratch the bodies of the dead out of their graves.
The Lyon‥will not seek his prey himself, but sends his Caterer, or Jack-call to run about to seek it.
Close by, their Fire-ships, like Jackals, appear, Who on their Lions for the prey attend.
They must not be like the Joe-caul, which provides food for the Lyon.
An Habitation only for Wolves, Foxes, and Chacals.
Those Asiatick Foxes, vulgarly named by Travellers, Jakhals, or Jacals.
A great many Siacalles, or Wild Dogs.

bibMain.w: Hist. Acct. Brit. Trade Caspian Sea

q.qt: The Shackalls in the woods bark'd and howl'd.
He who has been bitten by a dog, a shakal, or an ass.
From burial fields the midnight chacal cried.
The shriek of the jackal bursting on the ear in the silence of night.
I am a brother to jackals 1611 dragons, and a companion to ostriches.

s4.def: fig. A person who acts like a jackal, esp. one who does subordinate preparatory work or drudgery for another, or ministers to his requirements.

q.qt: Those lesser ones‥are but so many Jack-calls to fetch him in store of prey.

div.def: attrib. and Comb., as jackal cry, jackal-hunting, jackal skin; jackal-headed adj.; jackal buzzardan African species of buzzard (Buteo jackal).

q.qt: The Commodities‥are Slaves‥Chacal-Skins.
Nor give my voice to Slavery's Jackall cry.

etymSect.etym: See a

s4.def: A figure of a man, set up to be pelted: an ancient form of the sport of ‘Aunt Sally’, practised during Lent. Hence fig. a butt for every one to throw at. arch.

q.qt: Ever upon Easter day, All Jack a Lents were cast away.
See now how wit may be made a Iacke-a-Lent when 'tis vpon ill imployment.
Thou‥Travaild'st to Hamsted Heath, on an Ash-we'nsday, Where thou didst stand sixe weekes the Iack of Lent, For boyes to hoorle, three throwes a penny, at thee.
Those Factious Few‥Set up a Jack of Lent, and throw at it.

s4.def: transf. A puppet; an insignificant or contemptible person. arch.

q.qt: You litle Iack-a-Lent, haue you bin true to vs?
To make the Parliament a mere Jack-a-Lent, and as insignificant a nothing as the single person.
What encouragement have I given you, Jack-a-Lent, to attack me with your tenders?
Can a jack-o'-lent believe his few senses on such a dark night or can't he?

s4.def: A Lenten dish; a Lenten faster; Lent personified. Obs.

q.qt: A Jack-a-Lent, made of a red Herring and a Leek.
Sprats need no description, being one of Jack-a-lents principle pages.

s4.def: = Jack-o'-lantern2. Obs.

q.qt: The Aurora Borealis is as frequent in the Northern Countries as a Jack of Lent is here.

Entry.vfSectLoose: Forms: α. MEIac Napes (Nape), Iack (Iake) Napys, ME–15Iack napis, 15Iacke Napes (napes), Iack-, iackenapes. β. 15Iack(e a napes, (Iack of Napes), 16–17Jack-a-napes; 16Jack-a-nape. γ. 15–16Iack(e) an apes (Apes), Iack(e)-an-apes (-Apes), (16Jack and Apes); 16Jack an Ape, Jack-an-Ape, 18jack-an-ape, jackanape. δ. 15–16Iack(e)-anapes, 16jacanapes, jackanaps, jackinapse, 16–jackanapes; 16Jackanape. pl.-apes, -apeses, (†-aps's).

etymSect.etym: Precise origin uncertain. So far as yet found, the word appears first as an opprobrious nickname of William de la Pole, Duke of Suffolk (murdered 1450), whose badge was a clog and chain, such as was attached to a tame ape. Hence, in a poem of 1449 (see 2a), in which other noblemen are denominated by their badges or heraldic emblems, as the Swan, fiery Cresset, Portcullis, Wheat-ear, etc., Suffolk is styled ‘the Ape-clogge’, and in somewhat later satirical invectives is referred to as an ape, and entitled Jack Napes; this being inferentially already a quasi-proper name for a tame ape, as it is seen to be in 1522. (The converse hypothesis, that Suffolk was for some other reason called ‘Jack Napes’, and that this nick-name was transferred from him to the ape, does not, on a review of the facts, seem probable.) But of Jack Nape or Napes, and its relation to an ape or apes, no certain explanation can be offered; it was perhaps, in its origin, merely a playful or whimsical name for a tame ape, and the n- might arise as in nunckle and neye (birds-nie, pigs-ney), or as in the by-names Ned, Noll, Nell, and the -s might be in imitation of the -s of surnames such as Jakkes, Hobbes, Symmes, etc., already in use, so that ‘Jack Napes’ parodied a human name and surname. If this was the standing of the name, it is easy to understand that it might never attain to literary use, till it became the nick-name of Suffolk. Be this as it may, the fact remains that Jack Napes is the earliest form, of which Jack-a-Napes, Jack of Napes (? Naples), Jack-an-ape, Jack-and-apes, are later perversions, apparently attempts of ‘popular etymology’ to make the expression more intelligible. In accordance with this view, the original sense is here taken as ‘ape’, of which the use in sense 2a is treated as a derived application, though it is in point of date the earliest use that has come down to us, and may possibly, with further evidence, have to stand first.

s4.def: Name for a tame ape or monkey.

s6.def: as the quasi-proper name of an ape. Obs.

q.qt: Noddinge, beckinge and mowinge, as it were Iacke a napes.

bibMain.w: Why come ye nat to Courte

q.qt: He grynnes and he gapis As it were iack napis.
He delyted in them, as we in ye gestures of Iacke napes.
They mocke and mow at them like Iack a napes.
Women that haue as much knowledg in phisick or surgery as hath Iackeanapes.
Iacke Napes, forsooth, did chafe because I the Owle eate my Slaue the Bat.
Some like him to a trimmed Asse, And some to Iacke-an-Apes.
Can Iack an Ape be merry when his clog is at his heel?

s6.def: as common noun: An ape, a monkey. arch.

q.qt: To mockynge to mowynge to lyke a Iackenapes.
A sight of Asses then, there stoode in battell ray, With Iacke an apeses on their backes.
The Reader cannot chuse but haue as great delight therein, as a Iacke an Apes hath in a Whip.
A Jack an Ape, a cat, or some such contemptible creature.
Like fawning Curre, or mopping Jack-an-Ape.

Dressing him out like a jackanapes, and giving him money to play the fool with.

I could see him climbing like a jackanapes.

s4.def: Applied to a person compared to an ape.

s6.def: as quasi-proper name, applied to the Duke of Suffolk (whose badge was an ape's clog and chain). Obs.

q.qt: The Rote is ded, the Swanne is goone, The firy Cressett hath lost his lyght;‥The White Lioun is leyde to slepe Thorouȝ the envy of the Ape clogge (gloss. Southfolk).

Jack Napys, with his clogge Hath tiede Talbot oure gentille dogge. Wherfore Beamownt, that gentille rache. Hath brought Jack Napis in an eville cache.‥ God save the kynge and God forbede That he suche apes any mo fede.
Jac Napes wolde one the see a maryner to ben, With his cloge and his cheyn, to seke more tresour.‥ For Jac Napes also For Jac Nape soule Placebo and Dirige.

s6.ch_firstSource: Letters and Papers of Henry VIII
s6.def: as quasi-proper name of a man using the tricks, or displaying the qualities, of an ape. Obs.

q.qt: Churlish people‥who shew but, as the proverb is, Jack of Napes charity in their hearts.
It was nothing else, but a loftie tricke of iacke an apes.

s6.def: as common noun: One who is like an ape in tricks, airs, or behaviour; a ridiculous upstart; a pert, impertinent fellow, who assumes ridiculous airs; a coxcomb. (The current use.) Also, playfully, A pert forward child, a ‘monkey’.

q.qt: This the Divell's Jackanapes made pastime to Lucifer.

etymSect.etym: A derivative of Jack, apparently with the ending of kangaroo.

s4.def: A man newly arrived from England to gain experience in the bush (see quot. 1885); an inexperienced young colonist. Now esp. a cadet or novice on a sheep-station or cattle-station.
