div.def: Comb.

q.qt: Your poor industrious jackass-driver.
To be jumped upon by a jackass-headed old idiot like that.

sub.def: a sailing ship having the same sails as a barquentine but rigged in a manner varying in some respect from the orthodox barquentine rig.

q.qt: On the 10th instant there was launched from the building-yard of Messrs. J. and J. Hall, at Arbroath, a beautifully modelled jackass barque, named the Princess Alice, of 190 tons N.N.M.
The sails of a barquentine and of a jackass barque are precisely the same.

It sometimes occurred that a ship was rigged, for example, with a fore-and-aft sail on the lower mainmast and square sails on the top and topgallant masts.‥ In England all such types of pseudo-barques were called jackass barques.

sub.def: home-made brandy.

q.qt: Intoxicating liquor, to wit, one pint bottle of jackass brandy.
Jackass brandy, a home-made brandy with a powerful ‘kick’.
A still in operation and a stock of jackass brandy close by.

sub.def: ‘a brig with square topsail and topgallant-sail instead of a gaff-topsail’ (Cent. Dict.).

q.qt: The potatoes would have to be paid for before that ‘jackass brig’ could sail.
She is what is called a jackass brig. She has one mast square rigged and the other is schooner rigged, with topsail.
There was a jackass brig, no main course, main yard high up, rigged like a topsail schooner on main mast.

sub.def: the raw copal of Zanzibar: see quots.

q.qt: These places supply only the raw or unripe Copal, locally called Chakazi, and by us corrupted to Jackass.
The raw, or true, copal is called chackaze, corrupted by the Zanzibar merchant to jackass copal.

sub.def: an African antelope, the singsing.
a fish of the Australian seas (Chilodactylus macropterus), highly esteemed as food.

q.qt: Morwong, the New South Wales name for the fish Chilodactylus macropterus; also called the Carp and Jackass-fish.

sub.def: (see quot. and cf. donkey-frigate: frigate2b).

q.qt: ‘What do you mean by a jackass frigate?’ inquired I. ‘I mean one of your twenty-eight gun ships, so called, because there is as much difference between them and a real frigate, like the one we are sailing in, as there is between a donkey and a race-horse.’
The skipper looks anxiously toward the man of war, a jackass frigate, lying lower down the harbour.

sub.def: a common species of penguin (Spheniscus demersus), so called from its cry.

q.qt: The famous Jackass Penguin.
Commonly called the ‘Jackass Penguin’, from its habit, while on shore, of throwing its head backwards, and making a loud strange noise like the braying of that animal.

sub.def: (see quot.).

q.qt: When the pick is much used as a lever, the head is frequently formed‥with a projecting wing to afford increased support to the helve. This is called a jackass pick.

sub.def: = jack-rabbit

q.qt: All ideas of blue mountains, vast rolling prairies, etc., were cut short by a jackass-rabbit bounding from under our horses' feet.
Jackass rabbits (the Californian hare), and numbers of‥grey‥land squirrels‥scampered‥over the flats.

sub.def: of a schooner, having three masts with square sails set on the foremast and having no main topmast.

q.qt: October 19th‥passed a jackass-rigged craft.
There is another class of trading schooner, with three masts.‥ When it sets square sails on the foremast it is sometimes called jackass rigged.

sub.def: a schooner which is jackass-rigged.

q.qt: Jackass-schooner, still used occasionally of a schooner without main-topmast.
‘Jackass’ schooners‥were so called because they were square rigged forward like a tops'l schooner, but had a ketch's mizzen.
A ‘jackass schooner’ has no main topmast.

sub.def: (intr.) to ride a jackass.

q.qt: Driving in a Russian telega, or jackassing in Egypt.

sub.def: the character of a jackass (see 2), gross folly or stupidity; (with pl.) something characteristic of a jackass, a piece of folly.

q.qt: The genius of jackassery is not always to rule us.
He will clothe his body after the latest jackasseries of the masher.

sub.def: the action of making a jackass of, stultification.

q.qt: Acting on the principle of the general jackassification of mankind,‥he abuses them right and left.

sub.def: = jackassery

q.qt: Calling names, whether done to attack or to back a schism, Is‥a great piece of jack-ass-ism.

sub.def: the quality of being a jackass, gross foolishness.

q.qt: The crimes of pedantry, stupidity, jackassness.
To convey such news‥was the very essence of Jackassness.

publicationInfo.pubStatement: This entry has not yet been fully updated (first published 1900).
Second edition, 1989; online version December 2013. <>; accessed . An entry for this word was first included in New English Dictionary, 1900.

etymSect.etym: Echoic: influenced by Jack

s4.def: A local name for the fieldfare.

q.qt: Fieldfare (Turdus pilaris)‥Jack bird. From its cry. Cf. Chack chack (Luxemburg), Claque (Normandy).

s4.def: ‘A bird of the South Island of New Zealand, Creadion cinereus’ (Morris Austral Eng.).

q.qt: I have‥adopted the name of Jack-bird, by which it is known among the settlers in the South Island. Why it should be so called I cannot say, unless this is an adaptation of the native name Tieke‥the equivalent, in the Maori vernacular, of our Jack.

publicationInfo.pubStatement: This entry has not yet been fully updated (first published 1900).
Second edition, 1989; online version June 2012. <>; accessed . An entry for this word was first included in New English Dictionary, 1900.

etymSect.etym: Sense of jack uncertain: taken by some as jack, but may be Jack

s6.def: A large strong boot the top of which came above the knee, serving as defensive armour for the leg, worn by cavalry soldiers in the 17th and 18th centuries; also, a large boot coming above the knee, worn by fishermen and others, and also spec. by German soldiers during the Nazi regime.

q.qt: He had a light bob Periwig‥and a pair of Jack-Boots.
Should they meet a Man on Horseback, in his Breeches and Jack-Boots.
Leather, so dress'd that it is not inferior to Iron, like our Jack-Boots.
Two jack-boots concealed, in part, the well-mended knees of an old pair of buckskin breeches.
A meagre but fiery postilion, who with tremendous jack-boots and cocked hat was floundering on before him.
Jack-boots with long brass spurs.
Either the British way shall survive or the Nazi jackboot and whip shall take its place.
There were jackboots to be seen, iron crosses were pinned to the pockets of a few green shirts.

s6.def: fig. Military oppression; rough bullying tactics. Also attrib.

q.qt: Some insults were offer'd to some of the Lords & Commons in their Coaches as they went down with a Cry of Wilkes & Liberty & no Jack Boot.
A large numerical majority‥excluded from power and honour by a mere jack-boot minority.
The writers' trials and the jackboot on Prague have made it quite clear that Brezhnev and Kosygin's views on liberalism are akin to Stalin's.
He also objected strongly to what he called your jackboot methods when you interviewed Mrs Hurd.
This‥attempt by the Government to bludgeon this Bill through with jackboot tactics.
The clumsy look of a French jackbooted postilion.
Silent, jack-booted watchers standing outside frightened houses.
The once-jackbooted Germans.
He stood‥with his jackbooted legs apart‥as if to underline what they'd done in the name of Nazi justice.

publicationInfo.pubStatement: This entry has not yet been fully updated (first published 1900).
Second edition, 1989; online version June 2012. <>; accessed . An entry for this word was first included in New English Dictionary, 1900.

etymSect.etym: Jack + boy

s4.def: A boy employed in menial work; spec. a stable-boy, groom, or postillion. Cf. jockey

q.qt: Jacke boy,‥fayne thou woldist witen.
Rather make Lacky of Iack boy thy Nagge 1580 Iack boie thy wag.
They must haue the stones gathered off in winter‥by little Iackboyes and girles.
Why Iacke boy, ho boy, and as much newes as thou wilt.
Jack-boy, a postillion.
She‥uttered coarse and shameful words, such as the most shameless groom or jack-boy would scarce pronounce.

publicationInfo.pubStatement: This entry has not yet been fully updated (first published 1900).
Second edition, 1989; online version December 2013. <>; accessed . An entry for this word was first included in New English Dictionary, 1900.

etymSect.etym: Jack7: because used in roasting-jacks.

s4.def: A chain each link of which consists of a double loop of wire, resembling a figure of 8, but with the loops in planes at right angles to each other; the links are not welded.

q.qt: If you'l make use of any ornaments, I've a couple of jack-chains at your service.
Here you see‥a great Lord bowing to a Fishmonger, or Scrivener with a Jack-chain about his neck.
Six lengths of jack-chain.
Much stronger than ordinary welded or jack chains.

s4.ch_firstSource: Terms used in Forestry and Logging
s4.def: Logging. (See quot. 1905.)

bibMain.ser: (Bull. U.S. Dept. Agric., Bureau Forestry, No. 61)

q.qt: Jack chain, an endless spiked chain, which moves logs from one point to another, usually from the mill pond into the sawmill.

publicationInfo.pubStatement: This entry has not yet been fully updated (first published 1900).
Second edition, 1989; online version June 2012. <>; accessed . An entry for this word was first included in New English Dictionary, 1900.

etymSect.etym: Jack4b + daw Formerly stressed jack-ˈdaw (in Johnson 1755, Walker 1791, Todd 1818; still in Scotl.) Ash 1775 has ˈJackdaw.

s6.def: The common name of the daw (Corvus monedula), one of the smallest of the crow family, which frequents old buildings, church towers, etc.; it is easily tamed and taught to imitate the sound of words, and is noted for its loquacity and thievish propensities.

q.qt: Not all vnlyke vnto Isopes choughe, whom we commonlye call Iacke dawe.
Some cackles like a Henne, or a Iacke Dawe.
Choughes and iack dawes: the veriest theeves‥especially for silver and gold.
And may the Jack-daws still the Steeples hold.
Jackdaws building with us under the ground in rabbit-burrows.
In and out, Through the motley rout, That little Jackdaw kept hopping about.
The jackdaw‥could not keep silence to save his life, but must talk after his fashion.

s6.def: A species of grackle or ‘blackbird’ (Quiscalus major) of the Southern United States.

q.qt: Boat-tailed Grackle, Jackdaw. Of large size, with long, much keeled and graduated tail.

s4.ch_firstSource: History of the Tryall of Cheualry
s4.def: fig. Applied contemptuously to a loquacious person.

q.qt: Bowyer a Captayn?‥a very Iackdaw with his toung slit.
With City-Jack-daws; That make Staple-Laws, To Measure by Yards and Ells.

s4.def: attrib. and Comb., in reference to the Fable of the Jackdaw decked out with peacock's feathers, or to the furtive and secretive habits of the bird.

q.qt: Jack-daw poets with their stolen feathers.
In the Bodleian Library, where they now rest, thanks to the jackdaw-like propensities of Mr. Secretary Pepys.

publicationInfo.pubStatement: This entry has not yet been fully updated (first published 1900).
Second edition, 1989; online version December 2013. <>; accessed . An entry for this word was first included in New English Dictionary, 1900.

etymSect.etym: jack + -ed.

s6.def: Clothed in or armed with a jack (see jack1). Obs.
Hardened and thickened as leather for jack-boots.

q.qt: The peple was iakkyd and saletted and riottously disposid.
Their brown Skins, from Knee to Foot, Are jack'd like Trooper's stubborn Boot.
Dagger or sword point will not well make its way through the jacked doublings of those hides.
Made of double jacked leather.

publicationInfo.pubStatement: This entry has not yet been fully updated (first published 1900).
Second edition, 1989; online version June 2012. <>; accessed . An entry for this word was first included in New English Dictionary, 1900.

etymSect.etym: Irish diminutive of Jack

s4.def: A contemptuous designation for a self-assertive worthless fellow.

q.qt: A buckeen, a jackeen, a squireen, or any of the intermediate classes.
‘Jackeens’ loitering about the Dublin Theatres.
In manner and bearing he is a superb Jackeen.

publicationInfo.pubStatement: This entry has not yet been fully updated (first published 1900).
Second edition, 1989; online version June 2012. <>; accessed . An entry for this word was first included in New English Dictionary, 1900.

etymSect.etym: jack + -er.

s6.def: One who jacks, in various senses; e.g. one who hunts or fishes with a jack; one who jacks or throws.
jacker-off, jacker-up: see quots. 1921, 1921.

bibMain.w: Census Eng. & Wales: Instr. Clerks classifying Occupations & Ages

q.qt: It was in the lace factory that the lad was set to work as a ‘jacker-off’.
Jacker-off (lace); takes off from bobbins, waste lengths of unused threads, and winds them on to large wooden bobbins, using a small winding machine.
Jacker-up (lead pencil making); places a number of glued pencils together in a clamp, and screws down clamp to make glueing secure; removes pencils when clamping is complete.
Three-fourths of the children were jackers-off or ‘piecers’.

publicationInfo.pubStatement: This entry has not yet been fully updated (first published 1900).
Second edition, 1989; online version June 2012. <>; accessed . An entry for this word was first included in New English Dictionary, 1900.

Entry.vfSectLoose: Forms: MEiaquet, iaquette, ME–15iaket, iakette, 15iakett, iackett(e, iakket, iacquet(e, -quit, iakquet, ME–16iacket, 16–jacket.

etymSect.etym: Old Frenchjaquet, jacquet, diminutive of jaque: jack

s6.def: An outer garment for the upper part of the body: orig. the same as, or a shorter form of the jack; now, an outer garment with sleeves, reaching no lower than the waist, worn by boys (as an Eton jacket) and by men in certain occupations; also a short coat without tails (as a Norfolk jacket), worn in shooting, riding, cycling, etc.Also as second element in shooting-, smoking-, tennis-jacket, and the like.

q.qt: Ffor makynge off a jaket off crymysyn clothe ffor my sayd lurd, ij.s. iiij.d.
Rede clothe to make jakettes of to þe saudeours.
Donaas the doblet maker Hath performed my doublet And my Iaquet Fr. paltocque.
Item I giff my white chamlett iakett to be a vestiment to our lady chapell aforsaid.
Iacket that hath but four quarters, jacquette.
The souldiers thought good that it Christ's seamless coat should bee kept whole vncut, and that sum of them shoulde haue the whole iacket to whose lotte it shoulde chaunce.
Hoqueton, a Iacket, a cote of armor.
A comone garmente‥suche as we call a Ierken or Iackett withoute sleues.
Some of them have Jackets made of Plantain leaves, which were as rough as any Bears skin.
Jacket, a sort of Garment in Use among Country-People.
The women put on their husbands hats and jackets.
The royal archers led the way, clothed in jackets of vermilion, red, white, and green.
Before the young American is put into jacket and trousers, he says ‘I want something which I never saw before’.
You were only a boy in jackets.

s6.ch_subject: Crafts and Trades/Costume|Sport and Leisure/Horses and Riding/Horse Racing
s6.def: That worn by a jockey in horse-racing; now a loose-fitting blouse of silk or satin, of the owner's distinctive racing colours. Hence, to send in his jacket, take away his jacket, retain his jacket, etc. See J. Rice Hist. Brit. Turf1879.

q.qt: The Duke of Bedford‥very nearly requested him Chifney senior to send in his jacket.
Sam Chifney‥mounted the magnificent ‘purple jacket with scarlet sleeves, and gold-braid buttons‥’ of the Prince.

Jockey Club law does not acknowledge such a process as ‘sending in a jacket’.‥ But if masters‥force a senior jockey to retain their jacket, they are bound to give him their mounts, and not to ‥prevent him from seeking for more considerate masters elsewhere.
He thought nothing‥of putting a silk jacket into his pocket, and riding 70 or 80 miles to a meeting, to oblige a friend.
I glanced at the card to see the entries. It ran:—‥4. Colonel Ross's Silver Blaze (black cap, red jacket).

s6.def: A woman's outer garment analogous to that of boys or men, either loose or close-fitting, and of varying length.

q.qt: Her usual dishabille‥is, an ordinary stuff jacket and petticoat.
To the detriment of that young lady's muslin jacket.

s6.def: Locally in U.S., = waistcoat. (Cent. Dict.)
Applied to something worn or fastened round the body for other purposes than clothing; as a strait-jacket, a swimming jacket.

Phrases. to line one's jacket (obs.): see quot. 1611. to dust, swinge, thrash, trim, etc. (a person's) jacketto dust (a person's) jacketto swinge (a person's jacket)to thrash (a person's) jacketto trim (a person's) jacket, to give him a beating. Also in phrases referring to breadth or narrowness of opinions, etc. (quots. 17921896). See also dust6b.

q.qt: He stuffes himselfe soundly, hee lines his iacket throughly with liquor.
I'll substantially thrash your jacket for you.
I will swinge his Jacket for him.
They were not able to make a schism in their short and narrow jacket.
I'll dust your jacket if you do that again.
He had ‘widened the jacket’ of his Scotch theological training by mastering the results of the most advanced German speculation.

s6.def: Mil.colloq. (See quots.) Obs.

q.qt: Lieut. Tanner obtained his ‘jacket’, and was the beau ideal of a horse-artillery officer.
Unitl 1895‥a ‘jacket’ —i.e., a post in the Royal Field Horse Artillery—might be given to an officer of Field Artillery or of Garrison Artillery.
Jacket (Military), a soldier who wears a jacket (chiefly cavalry or horse artillery).
Jacket, to get the: colloquial for an appointment to the Royal Horse Artillery.

s6.def: An outer covering, coating, or casing of any kind placed round a vessel, as a pipe, steam-cylinder, or boiler, to protect it, prevent escape of access of heat, etc. See also steam-jacket

q.qt: I enclose my brewing vessel in another vessel which I call the case or jacket.
The enclosing of the cylinder in a jacket or drum of wood.
Heating a fluid by means of a steamwarmed jacket or coil.
The crucible is to be covered by the plumbago jacket.
The evaporation is best done in a vessel like a glue-pot, in which the milk is not boiled, but is surrounded by a jacket of boiling water.

s6.def: A paper cover or wrapper issued with a bound book, usually with the title printed upon it. See also dust-jacketdust5.

q.qt: It was arrayed in a handsome purple ‘jacket’, and bore the crown and monogram of George III.
Paper jackets are being printed for it, worded as shown.

s6.def: U.S. ‘A folded paper or open envelop containing an official document, on which is indorsed an order or other direction respecting the disposition to be made of the document, memoranda respecting its contents, dates of reception and transmission, etc.’ (Cent. Dict.)
Ordnance. A coil or cylinder of wrought iron or steel placed around the barrel of a gun to strengthen or protect it.

q.qt: This improvement consists in the addition of a steel jacket to the body of the gun from the breech to beyond the trunnions.
The tube‥is encircled by a single band or jacket (Mantel, in German), shrunk on.
A second gun‥having a jacket of cast steel.
Sheathing the gun tube in an insulating jacket of cloth, plastic material or aluminum plate.

s6.def: The natural (usually hairy) covering or ‘coat’ of various animals; the fleece (of a sheep), hair (of a dog), fur (of a cat), etc.; also the skin (of a seal, fish, etc.).

q.qt: These kindes of Serpents‥The Scythale is admirable in her varied Iacket.
Herds of Actinia bellis in prime condition—jackets as red as a Kentish cherry.
The recent high price of long wool has tempted some flockmasters to neglect the form, in their eagerness to secure a heavy jacket.
As fast as one seal is clubbed or shot the skinner with the sharp knife turns it out of its ‘jacket’, as the skin with the attached blubber is styled.
A two-pound perch boiled in its own jacket, and served up with parsley sauce.
I have seen her in July with a magnificent jacket, while every other cat had next to none.

s6.def: The skin of a potato (when cooked with the skin on).

q.qt: Potatoes‥boiled unpeeled—or as we say, ‘in their jackets’.
A pot of potatoes in their jackets.

s6.def: Pathol. A formation coating some organ.

q.qt: This white jacket, which may be a quarter of an inch thick, easily peels off the subjacent liver.

s6.def: A young seal; so called from the rough fur. Newfoundland.

div.def: General attrib.

q.qt: The laundress‥had left a deep triangular singe in the very centre of the jacket-back.
Oliver‥was at once lugged along the streets by the jacket-collar at a rapid pace.
The crew lost their jacket knives.
He thrust the first book into his jacket-pocket which he could lay his hand on.
What skirt's in fashion now; the Jacket-way, Down to the hams?

sub.def: a dress-bodice coming down over the skirt like a jacket; also a jacket-shaped under bodice.

q.qt: Over her jacket-bodice she wears a woollen shawl.

sub.def: a crown (crown29b), often of porcelain or vinyl, fitted over an existing natural crown, which is usually ground down to receive it.

q.qt: The so-called jacket crown is often a most useful style of construction.
Very occasionally, jacket crowns may be used as retainers in anterior bridgework.
One of my jacket crowns is loose.

sub.def: a potato cooked in its jacket, i.e. unpeeled.

q.qt: Jackutty-taters, potatoes boiled with their skins on.
A young woman was handing him ‘jacket’ potatoes.
You'll fare better on Rosie's stew and my baked jacket potatoes.

sub.def: a poultice placed between two folds of stuff.

q.qt: A jacket poultice of linseed is a common and for the most part a good application.

sub.def: (or ) in the manner of a jacket.

q.qt: Aloft their shirts they weare a garment iocket wise.

sub.def: without a jacket.

q.qt: Her son‥burst into the room, jacketless.
Tess had come out with her milking-hood only, naked-armed and jacketless.

sub.def: of the nature of a jacket.

q.qt: His coat was a light jackety sort of thing, with little pockets behind.

s6.ch_subject: Manufacturing and Industry/Oil and Gas Industry
s6.def: Oil Industry. The steel frame which is fixed to the sea-bed and forms the support structure of an oil production platform.

q.qt: Earlier platforms in the southern North Sea had located the superstructure directly on to the piles supporting the jacket.
Welding near the water's surface to attach the deck to the jacket will be eliminated.
This massive object was the base of an oil platform—what is known in the business as a jacket.
A £15 million contract for the construction of a riser platform‥consists of a 5,500 tonne jacket, a 1,300 tonne deck and 2,000 tonnes of piling.

s6.ch_firstSource: Journal of the American Statistical Association
s6.def: U.S.Mil. slang, Police slang, and Criminals' slang. A personal file or dossier; spec. a criminal record.

q.qt: One person‥was assigned to the files to remove the jackets (prison records) for each institution and to allocate these jackets daily to the eight supervisors.
Today our jackets (records) went before the squadron board.
You been reading my jacket too?
Jersey state police got a fat jacket on him.
Men got terminated for that. But they also had sloppy jackets, a code violation here, a write-up there. Despite Lester's excessive arrests, his jacket was clean.

s6.def: U.S.Prison slang. In extended use: a reputation, esp. for objectionable or treacherous behaviour. Occas. with prefixed noun indicating the nature of the offence.

q.qt: You wouldn't want to be a chicken thief, would you? That's a hell of a jacket to carry.

‘That kid in your cell's got a jacket.’ ‘What kind of jacket?’ ‘A freak jacket. He's a righteous little freak. I wondered what kind of freight they'd loaded you with, so I eased into the record room this morning to take a look.’
If you get sent to Vacaville you are classified as having a serious personality or character disorder. And man, you'll wear that jacket for the rest of your life.
Rooski cant go back to the pen. With his snitch jacket, he wouldnt last a week.

So my confidential prison file—which I'm never allowed to see‥—has me wearing two ‘jackets’, that of a racist mastermind and that of a compulsively violent misogynist. They put the jackets on me, and there's nothing I can do to remove them.

publicationInfo.pubStatement: This entry has not yet been fully updated (first published 1900).
Second edition, 1989; online version June 2013. <>; accessed . An entry for this word was first included in New English Dictionary, 1900.

s6.def: trans. To cover with or enclose in a jacket (in various senses of the n.).

q.qt: The cylinders of the Mooltan's engines are ‘jacketed’, as it is termed,—that is, there is an upper pair of 43 inches' diameter, in which the dry steam is first used, at a pressure of 20 lb., and an outer cylinder of 96 inches' diameter, where it is worked expansively.
The ‘ice-box’ is also a metal chamber,‥jacketted all over with a non-conductor.
In Government offices, to jacket a document is, after scheduling, to enclose it with other papers referring to the same subject.
A Bible jacketed in American cloth upon the table.
Unfortunately, there are forty-five waiters to only forty jackets,‥perhaps‥the managers will be able to scrape together sufficient money to jacket the unhappy five.

s6.def: slang. (See quot. 1819.)

q.qt: To jacket a person‥is more properly applied to removing a man by underhand and vile means from any birth or situation he enjoys, commonly with a view to supplant him.

s6.def: To enclose (a person) in a strait-jacket.

q.qt: He found himself surrounded, jacketed, strapped, and collared.
They told me plainly that they would jacket me to death if I did not confess.

s4.def: dial. or colloq. To beat, thrash. (Cf. the phrases s.v. jacket1f) See also jacketing3.

q.qt: ‘I'll jacket him when he comes in’.

publicationInfo.pubStatement: This entry has not yet been fully updated (first published 1900).
Second edition, 1989; online version December 2013. <>; accessed . An entry for this word was first included in New English Dictionary, 1900.

etymSect.etym: jacket or jacket + -ed.

s4.def: Clothed, covered, or surrounded with a jacket (in various senses of the n.).

q.qt: Iacketed, tunicatus.
Those jacketted Gouda Cows.
I have seen baby London short-coated, and frocked, and breeched, and jacketed.
Jacketed Pans, for soups etc..

publicationInfo.pubStatement: This entry has not yet been fully updated (first published 1900).
Second edition, 1989; online version December 2013. <>; accessed . An entry for this word was first included in New English Dictionary, 1900.

etymSect.etym: jacket or jacket + -ing.

s4.def: = jacket2.

q.qt: This pipe is surrounded by a water jacketing, and kept cool by a running stream of water.

s4.def: Material, as cloth, etc. for making jackets.
colloq. A beating. Also fig.

q.qt: I don't work on Sundays. If I did, I'd get a jacketing.
The very worst ‘jacketing’ which the Colonel was capable of administering.

publicationInfo.pubStatement: This entry has not yet been fully updated (first published 1900).
Second edition, 1989; online version March 2013. <>; accessed . An entry for this word was first included in New English Dictionary, 1900.

etymSect.etym: the name of Jackfield, a village in Shropshire.

s4.def: Used attrib. to denote a kind of black-glazed pottery of a type manufactured in Jackfield in the 18th century. Also ellipt. as

q.qt: Collectors of English earthenware are generally inclined to assign the black so-called ‘Jackfield ware’ to Whieldon. Possibly the black glaze‥may have been added at Jackfield.
Leeds pottery dates from about 1750, and though the creamware is the commonest product, the factory also produced some rather nasty shiny black earthenware called ‘Jackfield’.
A smaller exquisitely modelled Jackfield ware jug.

publicationInfo.pubStatement: This entry has not yet been fully updated (first published 1976).
Second edition, 1989; online version June 2012. <>; accessed . An entry for this word was first included in A Supplement to the OED II, 1976.

etymSect.etym: Jack8 + frame

s4.def: The frame in which a jack or winch is fixed.

etymSect.etym: the name of Jack Ketch (or John Ketch, sometimes written Catch and Kitch), the common executioner 1663 (?)–1686. Partly on account of his barbarity at the executions of William Lord Russell, the Duke of Monmouth, and other political offenders, partly perhaps from apt association with the verb Ketch, catch, his name became notorious, was given to the hangman in the puppet-play of Punchinello, introduced from Italy shortly after his death, and became a common appellation. See Dict. National Biogr. s.v.

s4.def: An appellation for the common executioner or hangman.

s4.def: Statistics. A versatile method of reducing the bias of estimates and assessing their variability, using subsets of the available data which are often obtained by deleting a single value from the complete set.

q.qt: Turkey adopted the name ‘jackknife’ in 1958 for this procedure, since a boy scout's jackknife is symbolic of a rough-and-ready instrument capable of being utilized in all contingencies and emergencies.

The mean of results based on several subsamples is likely to be more biased than is a single result based on all the data, at least to the extent that the individual samples are small. A method with wide application, intended to ameliorate these problems, is the jackknife.
‘Jacknife’ sic, a method‥which reduces bias in estimation and provides approximate confidence intervals in cases where ordinary distribution theory proves difficult.
The jackknife proceeds by removing one observation at a time from the original data and recalculating the statistic of interest for each of the resulting truncated data sets.

etymSect.etym:
Cognate with Old Saxonquān wife, Old Icelandickván wife, (in poetry) queen (also as kvæn), Gothicqens woman an ablaut variant (lengthened grade) of the Indo-European base of quean; compare Sanskritjāni wife.In Old English a strong feminine, the reflex of the genitive singular of which (Old Englishcwēne) occas. survives into early Middle English (compare quene in quot. 13252), although levelling of the genitive singular in -es is found as early as the first half of the 12th cent. (compare quot. lOE2).
With sense 6a compare heaven queen and parallels cited at that entry; compare also post-classical Latinregina (6th cent. in this sense), Old Frenchreine (12th cent. in this sense: see rennet), Old High Germankuningin the Virgin Mary, lit. ‘queen’ (Middle High Germanküniginne, GermanKönigin).
With sense 6e perhaps compare quean
With sense 7b(a) compare post-classical Latinregina coeli the moon (Vulgate).
With sense 8a compare Middle Frenchroyne, variant of reine (1347 in this sense), post-classical Latinregina (14th cent. in this sense in the Latin version of the same source), Middle High Germanküniginne (13th cent. in this sense). Compare earlier fers
With sense 8b compare Middle Frenchroyne, variant of reine (1514 in this sense).
In sense 13 perhaps originally a variant of quean (see sense 3 at that entry), by association with this word, although compare the earlier quot. 189313.

s4.def: A woman, esp. a noblewoman; a wife, esp. of an important man. Obs.rare.Even in Old English, cwēn is not the usual term for ‘woman’ or ‘wife’; it is used in this sense only in poetry.

s6.def:
Chess. The most powerful chess piece belonging to each player, placed next to the king at the start of the game, and able to move in any direction along a rank, file, or diagonal on which it stands. Formerly also: †the position on the board attained by a pawn when it is queened (obs.rare).to make a queen: to promote a pawn into a queen; cf. queen2.
Now the strongest piece on the board, and capable of defending the king, the queen was originally the weakest, able to move only one square at a time; its power was greatly enhanced by a major revision of the rules in the 15th cent. The term fers (see fers) is now commonly used to distinguish the older piece, although fers and queen were formerly used interchangeably.

Traditionally slate used a range of names for the different sizes available, the more common including the following (measurements in inches): Lady (16 × 8), Viscountess (18 × 9), Countess (20 × 10), Marchioness (22 × 11), Duchess (24 × 12), Princess (24 × 14) and Queen (34 × 20). The practice was abandoned because of the different use of the terms by different quarries.

etymSect.etym:
Cognate with Old Frisianquik (West Frisiankwik, kwyk), Old Dutchquic (Middle Dutchquic, Dutchkwik, kwiek), Old Saxonquik (Middle Low Germanquik- (apparently only in compounds; compare also quik, noun: see below), German regional (Low German) quick), Old High Germanquec, quek, also (late) chechh-, cheg (Middle High Germanquec, also kec, Germankeck pert, bold, and Queck- (in compounds); compare also Germanquick lively ( Low German)), Old Icelandickvikr, kykr, Old Swedishqvikker, kviker (Swedishqvick), Old Danishqwik, qwig, qweg (Danishkvik, also kvæg), apparently related to Gothicqius alive, and also to Sanskritjīva, classical Latinvīvus, Lithuaniangývas, Old Church Slavonicživŭ, Early Irishbéu, béo (Irishbeó), Welshbyw (13th cent.) alive, living, ancient Greekβίος life, although the exact nature of the relationship is uncertain (see below).The second velar in the North and West Germanic forms (as opposed to the simple stem-final -w in Gothic) poses problems in explaining the etymological relationship with the Gothic form and with the forms in other branches of Indo-European; it has been variously explained as resulting from either dissimilation or reduplication in Germanic, or from an extended form of the Indo-European base.
The Old English forms cwicu, cucu reflect Germanic inflection according to the paradigm of the u-stems, whereas the form cwic shows the regular paradigm of Old English strong adjectives.
With use as noun in sense B. 1c, compare Old Frisianquik, quek, kuic, Middle Dutchquec, quec (Dutch †kwik), Middle Low Germanquik, quīk, quek, quēk, Danishkvæg (perhaps after Middle Low German). With sense B. 3 compare Middle Dutchquecke living flesh (early modern Dutchquick), Old Icelandickvikva, kvika flesh beneath the nails or hooves. With sense B. 4 compare slightly earlier quickset and earlier quickwood
With use as adverb compare quickly

sub.def: a type of clay found in northern areas (e.g. Scandinavia, Canada) typified by a high water content, which under certain conditions can spontaneously liquefy, sometimes causing large mudslides; cf. sense A. 18.

q.qt: In the Vaerdal landslip of May, 1893,‥the stream had been cutting against a clay bank in which there was ‘quick’ clay beneath the soil.

All kinds of soft clay are often called ‘quick’ clay; in a more restricted sense it means clay which has the property of being comparatively stiff when it lies in its original bed, but becomes fluid when it is set in motion.
A very soft and extremely sensitive clay, known in Norway as kvikkleire (quick-clay).
A special class of mudflows are those developing in quick clays which spontaneously liquefy and may flow readily on very gentle slopes, rafting houses, roads and trees appreciable distances.
The essential point about the quickclays is that they contain non-swelling clay minerals such as illite, chlorite and vermiculite, but not montmorillonite.

Clays formed in marine environments often have a much more open structure than those formed in fresh water: isostatic uplift leaves the structure in a metastable state which can be easily disrupted with the disastrous consequences of the quick clay flow slides that are common in Scandinavia.

Third edition, December 2007; online version March 2014. <>; accessed . An entry for this word was first included in New English Dictionary, 1902.

etymSect.etym:
Cognate with or formed similarly to Old Saxonquikōn to live (compare Middle Low Germanquicken, quēken to restore to life or vigour and also Old Saxonaquikōn: see aquick) the Germanic base of quick Compare also Middle Dutchquēken, queeken, quicken to bring to life, to refresh, to care for, also (rare) to be cheered (Dutchkweken; also as kwikken; compare also early modern Dutchquicken to live (in an apparently isolated attestation)), Old High Germanquekkan, checchēn to revive, to be alive, quicken, chicchen to bring to life, to restore life and vigour to (Middle High Germanquicken, German †quicken; now only in erquicken: see aquick).With sense 3 compare Old Icelandickveykja, kveikja, kveykva (with a different ablaut grade of the same base). In quot. 18533b after Old Icelandickveikja.
In Old English the prefixed form gecwician to give life to, bring to life (compare y-) is also attested. Compare also acwicianaquick, edcwician, geedcwician to be restored to life, to restore to life (compare ed-, y-).
In Middle English some examples can be difficult to distinguish from examples of quicken

s4.def: intr. Of a person, animal, plant, or their parts: to come to life; to revive; = quicken1c. Also fig.Obs.

etymSect.etym:
Anglo-Norman and Middle Frenchquiet, also quiete quiet, tranquil, in Anglo-Norman also ‘free, exempt’ (mid 13th cent. in Old French; Frenchquiet, now arch. and rare; compare the more common forms cited at quit) and its etymon classical Latinquiētus in a state of rest, asleep, inactive, making no noise, tranquil, undisturbed, free from war, at peace, free from agitation, (of the sea, atmosphere) free from storms, calm (e.g. quiēta statiō sheltered anchorage (Caesar); compare sense A. 11), in post-classical Latin also (of a debt) discharged (7th cent.), exempt, quit (9th cent.; frequently from 11th cent. in British sources; also as quittus: see quit), use as adjective of past participle of quiēscere to come to rest, to be quiet (see quiesce). Compare Old Occitanquet, Catalanquiet (1490), Spanishquedo (13th cent.), Portuguesequieto (15th cent.), Italianquieto (14th cent.). Compare also Frenchcoi quiet, still (now arch.: see coy). With use as adverb compare earlier quietlyAttested earlier as a surname, Nicholas Quiet (1254), although it is unclear whether this reflects the Middle English or the Anglo-Norman word.
On the see discussion at Q

s4.def: Physics. Of a period or region: marked by no local fluctuations of magnetism.

s4.def: Astron. Of the sun, a region of it, or a part of the solar cycle: not especially active; spec. marked by the absence (or a minimal number) of sunspots. Of other celestial objects: = radio-quietradio3.

q.qt: The purpose of these circuits is to squelch or quiet the receiver when sufficient signal for satisfactory reception is not present.
Squelch, to quiet a receiver automatically by reducing its gain in response to a specified characteristic of the input.

The noise‥will be placed at the squelch gate input to bias it on. This short-circuits the output of the detector to ground, preventing the audio amp from receiving this noise, and thus quieting the audio output.
Force feedback servoloops‥use inertial sensors as error signals to quiet a payload in a frequency range where the sensor is quiet.

etymSect.etym:
Origin uncertain.It has been suggested that the word is imitative of the birds' call (see quot. 1894), but this seems unlikely, as the call of the birds (all of which are relatively similar in size and appearance) is more reminiscent of zi: or si:si:, and Caribbean bird names of imitative origin tend to be formally similar to the calls uttered by the birds. Perhaps compare Haitian Creolepetit-chit, petite-chitte, denoting various kinds of warbler. Perhaps compare also Central American Spanish (Dominican Republic) siguita (1960 in J. Bond, or earlier), although a connection is unlikely on phonological grounds.
P. H. Gosse suggests (see quot. 1847) that the word is borrowed an African language, but no specific etymon has been identified.
No possible etymon has been found in the indigenous languages of the Caribbean.

s4.def: Any of various Jamaican tanagers, buntings, and related songbirds. Freq. with distinguishing word.banana, grass-, orangequit: see the first element.

q.qt: Black and yellow creeper. Banana Quit.

The name of Quit is applied without much discrimination by the negroes of Jamaica, to several small birds, such as the Banana Quit, which is a Creeper, and the Blue Quit, and Grass Quits which are finches; it is probably an African designation.
Quit, a name applied in Jamaica‥to several very different kinds of birds, probably from the notes they utter.
The Banana Quit is the Sugar-bird.
In and out of the corollas of these golden flowers dart woodpeckers‥, starlings‥, metallic humming-birds, innumerable small quits of variegated tints.
Blithe chirps a tiny quit, nesting.
Honey creeper‥. One species is called the banana-quit.
The quits (Coereba spp.) compete with the hummingbirds for Piscidia piscipula and the two tree species of Cordia.

s4.def: Astron. The point on the celestial sphere away from which a celestial object appears at any moment to be moving. Obs.rare.Apparently only in the writing of H. A. Newton.

q.qt: The goal and the quit of a moving body are those two points on the celestial sphere towards which and from which the body is moving.
It is further assumed‥that the quits and goals of the comets' motions relative to the sun are distributed equally over the surface of the celestial sphere.
Of the 839 comets‥267‥will have quits less than 45° from Jupiter's quit, while 38 of them will have quits less than 45° from Jupiter's goal.

s4.ch_firstSource: Monthly Rev. U.S. Bureau Labor Stat.
s4.def: U.S. The action or an instance of quitting, spec. of leaving a job or of departing a place. Also: a person who quits.

bibMain.w: Monthly Rev. U.S. Bureau Labor Stat.

q.qt: Separations include all quits, discharges, and lay offs for any reason whatsoever.
Quit, a voluntary separation from work by an individual worker, usually without notice of intention.
Our crew was rushing for an early Sat. quit and if we didn't get out of Palo Alto before, say, 11, we would get stuck in the hole there until afternoon.
The scope of the ‘voluntary quits’, persons who leave their jobs for any reason is not precisely tabulated.
Barrett was reluctant to estimate the impact of voluntary quits on the state.
Jack Quarry, who once drilled into his children a family motto he made up, ‘There's no quit in a Quarry’, then walked out of his son's life.
We've got an early quit.
The hospital superintendent‥didn't want to release me‥but I forced a personal responsibility quit-form out of him and signed it and left.
Receiving this quit-notice Governor Martin immediately convened his Council.
If‥he got a quit notice from the Kenyans, he'd wind up being stateless.
Already, some of the local councils have given quit notices to prostitutes to vacate their areas.

sub.def: the proportion of people in a particular industry, area, etc., who voluntarily leave their jobs over a certain period of time.

q.qt: Keen interest is therefore being shown by employers in the course of voluntary quit rates.
For both men and women workers, the lowest quit rates occur among skilled workers and professional and managerial workers.
41 per cent of married mothers do work; women's ‘quit-rate’ is lower than men's, making them most dependable workers.
Let us consider the indicator called the quit rate, which measures the number of people in manufacturing industries (per 100 employed) who voluntarily leave their jobs.
Employers‥had to confront initial hostilities to new equipment, the problems of persistently high quit rates and absenteeism.
Job satisfaction is measured by several tangible and intangible factors in the civilian economy, but quit rates or turnover rates are the bottom line.

etymSect.etym:
Anglo-Normanquit, quyt, Anglo-Norman and Old French, Middle Frenchquite, Anglo-Norman and Middle Frenchquitte (Frenchquitte) acquitted, cleared of a moral accusation or blemish, absolved of (a sin) (all 1100), released or exempt from (an obligation) (beginning of the 12th cent. in Anglo-Norman), cleared of (a debt), (of property) exempt or released from (taxes), (of taxes) no longer payable (all second half of the 12th cent.), (of property) in full possession, free of dues (early 14th cent. or earlier in Anglo-Norman) a post-classical Latin variant of classical Latinquiētusquiet with hypercorrect stress on the i (see discussion in Französisches etymol. Wörterbuch s.v. quietus). Compare post-classical Latinquitus, quittus exempt, immune (11th cent.), Old Occitanquit, quite (both 1150 or earlier; also quiti; Occitanquiti (now chiefly in quiti de apart from, except from)), Catalanquiti (12th cent.), Spanishquito (1207), Italian †quito (mid 13th cent. or earlier; also †quitto); also Old Frisianquyt, qwyt (West Frisiankwyt), Middle Dutchquīte, quijt (Dutchkwijt), Middle Low Germanquīt, Middle High Germanquit, quīt (Germanquitt, †queit), Old Icelandickvittr, Old Swedishqvitter (Swedishkvitt), Old Danish, Danishkvit.Like its French etymon and quit (see discussion at that entry), the word appears originally to have had a long vowel, but forms with a short vowel are found from a relatively early date. Forms of both types are also found in post-classical Latin, as well as in other European languages which borrowed the word ultimately Latin or French (see above). The and show spelling types which can normally be taken respectively as showing long and short vowels; the are ambiguous and hence have been placed in a separate sequence. The eventual predominance of the form with short vowel is probably connected with the parallel development in the verb, in which the use of quit as past participle probably played a part (see discussion at quit). Compare quite
The Scots forms quat, quatt are after the corresponding strong past participial forms at quit
With to go quit, to pass quit (see sense 1a) compare Anglo-Normanaler quite (1290 or earlier), Middle Frenchs'en aller quitte (early 15th cent. or earlier, used reflexively), Anglo-Normanpasser quite (early 14th cent. or earlier), Middle Dutchquite gaen.
With quit and free, free and quit (see senses 1a, 1c) compare Middle Frenchquitte et franc, franc et quitte (both late 14th cent.).
With to make (a person) quit of3b compare Middle Dutchquite maken (Dutch †qwijt maken), quite doen.
Sense 2 is rare in French and apparently not paralleled there until later (early 15th cent. in Middle French).

s6.def: Exempt or released from an obligation, debt, etc.; free, clear. Also (more emphatically) quit and free. to be quit for: to get off with, suffer nothing more than. to pass (also go, escape, etc.) quitto pass quitto go quitto escape quit: to escape unharmed; to go unchecked or unpunished. Now rare.

q.qt: For sum is strong. sum vnstrong. & mei fulwel beon quite 1230Corpus cwite & Paien god mid lesse.

Fif kniȝtes‥token an hond‥for þis seli man to paie; Þo was þis guode Man quit I-nov ase at þulke daie.
Bot so he wend have passed quite.

q.qt: Now am I fully quyt As twichand Venus of myn ald promyt Quhilk I hir maid.

q.qt: What faultes great men alwayes committe, Are pardoned still, and goeth quitte.

s6.def: Free, clear, rid of (a person or thing); acquitted of an offence. Also with †from.

Quyt is she Fro yow this yer.

Now is my modir quytte of the.

Quitt and cleere from doing wrong.
Throuch desyre‥to be quyte of the glore of a king.
Or ȝit thay beand accusit‥beis quyte and clengit thairof.

It is the doctor's duty to see you quit from all this.

s6.def: Law. Of real property: exempt or released of or from taxes, service, or other claims. Also more emphatically quit and free (also free and quit). quit and clear: free of encumbrances. Obs. (hist. in later use).

s4.def: Chiefly Sc.

etymSect.etym:
Anglo-Norman and Old French, Middle Frenchquiter, (chiefly Picardy and eastern, by analogy with verbs in -ier) quitier, Anglo-Norman and Middle Frenchquitter (Frenchquitter) to free, release (a person) (1150), to release, discharge, exonerate (a person) from (an obligation, payment of a debt, etc.), to exonerate (a person) from an accusation or blame (all second half of the 12th cent.; early 14th cent. or earlier in Anglo-Norman used reflexively in sense ‘to clear oneself of (an accusation or blame)’), to cede, yield, hand (a possession) over (to another person) (1175), to abandon, relinquish, renounce (a right or possession) (second half of the 13th cent.), to leave (a person) (second half of the 15th cent. with reference to permanently abandoning a spouse, mid 16th cent. with reference to temporarily taking leave of a person), to leave, go away from (a place) (1550), in Anglo-Norman also to repay (a debt) (mid 14th cent. or earlier) quite, quittequit Compare post-classical Latinquitare (from early 12th cent. in British and continental sources), post-classical Latinquittare (13th cent. in British and continental sources), Old Occitan, Occitanquitar (1150), Catalan †quitiar (end of the 12th cent.), quitar (late 13th cent.), Spanishquitar (1207), Portuguesequitar (13th cent.), Italian †quitare (late 13th cent. or earlier; also †quittare), Middle Dutchquīten (Dutchkwijten), Middle Low Germanquīten, Middle High Germanquīten, German †quitten, quittieren, Old Icelandickvitta, Old Swedishqvitta (Swedishkvitta), Danishkvitte (16th cent. as †quitte). Compare also post-classical Latinquietarequiet Compare quit and see discussion at that entry, and also acquit, requite, requitThe word appears to have had a long vowel originally, but forms with a short vowel are found from an early date, as also in French and Latin; compare the and respectively. A large number of spellings are ambiguous with regard to vowel length, and have hence been placed separately at the . Compare quit
The fact that the most common past tense and past participle forms were of the type quit, quitte, whereas regularized quited is considerably rarer in early use, may have helped the subsequent standardization on the short-vowel type quit. This may not yet have been complete in the mid 17th cent., as the orthoepist Thomas Hunt in 1661 regarded quit and quite as homophones, although his evidence is not necessarily reliable (see E. J. DobsonEng. Pronunc. 1500–1700 (ed. 2, 1968) II. §12). The long-vowel type quite is now only in archaic use.
During the first half of the 17th cent. the past tense and participle vary between quit and quitted, the former being freq. employed even by writers who use quit in the infinitive and present. In the late 19th and early 20th centuries quitted was the dominant past tense and past participle form in British English, as noted by N.E.D. (1902), but in recent years it has lost ground to quit, which N.E.D. (1902) characterized as chiefly used in regional dialects and colloquial American English.
In Middle English prefixed and unprefixed forms of the past participle are attested (see y-).
Scots forms with stem vowel e (as quet, whet) present difficulties of analysis; in the listing of forms above it is assumed that they show a development from the stem vowel i, but it is possible that (at least as they occur in modern use) the past tense and past participle forms in e should instead be regarded as showing strong past forms (hence Forms 2b and 3b rather than Forms 2a and 3a) and the corresponding present-stem forms be analysed as developed from them (and hence be placed at quat).

s6.def: To pay (a debt, penalty, due, etc.). Now arch. and rare.

s4.def: trans. To pay or bear responsibility for (a thing). Obs.

s6.def: To repay (a kindness, favour, etc.); to avenge (a wrong). Obs. (arch. in later use).

s6.def: To be equal to; to match, balance, redress. Freq. in to quit (the, one's) costto quit the costto quit one's costto quit cost. Obs.

Third edition, December 2007; online version March 2014. <>; accessed . An entry for this word was first included in New English Dictionary, 1902.

etymSect.etym: post-classical Latinqui tam, the first words of the clause qui tam pro domino rege quam pro se ipso sequitur ‘who sues as well for the lord the king as for himself’ (1684 or earlier in a British source; implied earlier in an allusion in a British source (1433)) classical Latinquī who (see who) + tam so much, to such a degree (see tanquam).With the extended use of the noun (as e.g. in quot. 1694A.) compare quot. 1688A. and also an earlier description of a corrupt lawyer as one whose declarations all contain Qui tam pro Domino Rege (T. JordanPictures of Passions, Fancies, & Affections (1641) sig. D6).

s4.def: A civil action brought under a criminal statute which allows a private individual to sue for a penalty both personally and on behalf of the Crown (government, or a specified public institution). Also in extended use: †a person who brings such an action, an informer (obs.). Cf. popular actionpopular2.

q.qt: Their being Sollicitors, Make-bates, Informers, proulers into the rights of other Mens Estates, Tamperers with Witnesses, Tales-men, Promoters of Office, Suers of others in the way of qui tam, &c. quam, &c.

An Information, is a kind of Declaration, as well at the Suit of the King, as the Informer (therefore called a Qui tam, from the words in the Information, A. B. qui tam pro Domino Rege, quam pro seipso sequitur) for the Breach of some Statute, or Penal Law, wherein some part of the Penalty, as a Moiety or Third part, is given to him; and may be either by Action of Debt, or Information.

s4.def: Designating, relating to, or characterized by this type of action.

etymSect.etym:
Cognate with Middle Dutchqueke (Dutchkweek), Middle Low Germanquēke, quecke, Old High Germanquecka (GermanQuecke (15th cent.) is Middle Low German), Swedishkvicka (1712; also kveka; chiefly regional), Danishkvik (probably German), probably the Germanic base of quick, so called on account of its vitality, i.e. its lush growth and indestructibility (compare quickbeam). Compare scutch, squitch, twitch, and perhaps compare queachIt is uncertain which plant is denoted by Old High Germanquecka (which is only found glossing Latinintiba).
In Old English a weak feminine; however, a strong masculine by-form is also attested.

etymSect.etym:
Anglo-Normanquiteclamer, quitecleimer (1276 or earlier) clamer quite (compare Middle Frenchclamer quitte; 1100 in Old French as quite clamer, clamer quite) clamerclaim + quitequit Compare post-classical Latinquietum clamare (frequently from 11th cent. in British sources; also as quiete clamare, quite clamare, quitclamare). Compare to claim quit, to quit claimclaim6.In sense 2 apparently subsequently re-interpreted as quit + claim; compare to quit claim toquit10d.
In , w in the initial consonant group kw has caused rounding of the following vowel and subsequently become silent. Forms such as quietclam, quieteclam are after quiet, quietus
With quitclaiming compare earlier quitclaimance, quitclaim

s4.def: trans. To declare (a person) free; to release, acquit, or discharge. Also intr. Now arch. and hist.

etymSect.etym: Apparently partly Anglo-Normanquite without opposition (1225 or earlier; rare; compare also Middle Frenchquittes totally (1341 in an apparently isolated use); quite, adjective (see quit)), and partly quit (although this is apparently not attested in the most closely corresponding sense until considerably later: see quit5); in sense probably influenced by Anglo-Norman and Middle Frenchquittement freely, unconditionally, completely (see quitement). Compare quitelyThe division of material in the forms list parallels that at quit and quit: see discussion at those entries.

s2.header: As an intensifier: completely, fully, entirely; to the utmost extent or degree.
s2.n:
In negative contexts, having the implication of closeness to the condition indicated.
In earlier use freq. placed after the word or phrase modified (now rare).

s6.def: With another, expressing contrast. Cf. sense A. 3c.

s6.def: With attributive adjectives following the article (esp. the indefinite article). Chiefly with adjectives expressing contrast, such as contrary (see also the quite contrary1), different, opposite, etc. a quite other: quite another (rare).

s6.def: Preceding nouns introduced by the indefinite article, in predicative use. Chiefly in negative contexts.

s6.def: With numerals. Now chiefly in negative contexts.

s6.def: Preceding a prepositional phrase containing an adjective expressing contrast. Cf. sense A. 2a. Obs.

q.qt: Trees, quite of another kind.

s4.def: With adverbs of manner (now esp. sentence adverbs).Since the emergence of sense A. 10, chiefly with particular kinds of adverb, esp. non-gradable ones.

s2.header: As an emphasizer: actually, really, truly, positively; definitely; very much, considerably; ‘implying that the case or circumstances are such as fully justify the use of the word or phrase thus qualified’ (N.E.D. (1902)).
s2.n: In senses A. 5aA. 5c now merged in or difficult to distinguish from A. 10, except when used with non-gradable adjectives.

s6.def: Preceding the indefinite article and an attributive adjective.

s6.def: With too. In later use chiefly colloq. and hyperbolical.

s6.def: With adjectives, past participles, and adverbs.

Traffic jams of broken pieces of ice can form quite suddenly as soon as ice cover begins to break up.

s6.def: With superlatives used attributively, preceding the definite article.

q.qt: A Character she had ever maintained among her Intimates, being of that number, every Individual of which is called quite the best sort of Woman in the World.
This is quite the best sweet preparation of rice that we have ever eaten.
And all that sort of thing, of which Dear Hawthorne's ‘quite’ the best describer.
The auditorium is quite the largest in the world.
Don't you think her letters are quite the best love-letters I get?
Exactly: quite the best kind of mediumship if you want to establish the identity of a spirit.
The high degree of accuracy‥quite the highest, surely, that can be attained.
Quite the blackest snarl from the trombones at the end‥that I have heard.

s4.def: Preceding a noun introduced by a determiner.In later usage, often used to indicate (freq. ironically) that the person or thing in question is regarded as particularly remarkable or impressive.

s6.def: With indefinite article. Formerly also occas. without article and with noun in plural.quite a few: see few2d. quite a number: see number9a.

q.qt: Something‥quite a scandal not to learn.
Far from a Lynx, and not a Giant quite.
It's quite a journey to come here.
That must have been quite a scene!
You are an odd creature!‥ You are a humourist.‥ Quite a humourist.
There's many a girl in the village that at my age is quite chits.
Council Bluffs is quite a place containing about 3 thousand inhabitants.
A daughter‥who died when quite a child.
Your letter gave me quite a brace.
An extension of the adverbial use as in ‘He is quite a lad’.
Comrade's quite a word. I suppose I oughtn't to chuck it around.
We had us a party last night—quite a party.
Sheila was in a much happier frame of mind.‥ As he was beginning to think she was quite a girl.
It had been quite a week and I wanted a day of relaxation.
The big side conservatory‥is quite an oasis for families.
The gardener‥had quite a job, for the garden was magnificent and vast.

s6.def: With definite article.quite the thing: see thing7a.

q.qt: Tho' Swearing is at present in tip top Taste, and quite the Thing, I don't believe the Generality of Gentlemen Cursers take a sufficient Time to recollect what they are going to do when they swear.
It silk is at once rich, tastey, and quite the thing.
I march'd the lobby, twirl'd my stick‥The girls all cry'd, ‘He's quite the kick!’
Pipes are quite the rage.
Quite the tippy for the boxes.
The Chancellor is not quite the right man for his‥place.
The proportions of the windows, and even the details of the cornice, had quite the grand air.
It was quite the thing to be in love.
He had quite the sense that she knew things he didn't.
I've been lecturing at Glasgow.‥ Now that I'm not there I'm quite the craze.
Ah. Quite the sybarite, aren't you?
She's turned into quite the spiffy New York gal.
Bunty‥was quite the thing nowadays in heels and stockings and even lipstick.

s6.def: orig. U.S. With some. Cf. quite something4.

q.qt: After quite some bluster two of them, named Compton and Grymes, undertook to settle it with a mill.
Quite‥common in Central Jersey in such expressions as ‘quite some’.
They have a burlesque every spring, and it's quite some fun.
You'll have quite some potatoes on the patch.
It was quite some excitement we had for a while.
They made quite some money out of this.
A wooden toy‥for £125. It was, as you will have gathered, quite some toy.
This patient has been drinking severely for quite some time.
This is quite some claim about a tunnel that will provide water for over 2.5 million people.
We could continue discussing templates for quite some time.

s4.def: With prepositional or adverbial phrases. Now rare.

q.qt: The Poupé‥did not arrive time enough for me to‥adjust my coiffure quite in the taste it might to have been in.
We began with Cotillons, and finished with country dances. It was the most elegant thing you ever saw in your life; everything quite in a style.
There are minerals and instruments quite at hand.
The account of the making of the first axe‥is told quite in the heroic style of Kingsley and Morris.
But this ‘high god’ is quite in the background, and is so much of a roi fainéant that nobody addresses any worship to him.

s4.def: With verbs. Now rare.

q.qt: I quite longed for you to share my admiration of it.
Lady Mildew‥quite haunts us.
A certain upstart commoner‥quite made love to me.
A great personage‥quite scoffed at their persisting to hold it.
She must have grown drowsy with the quiet and the heat of the fire, for she quite started when the door again opened.
This quite upset me.
The reason which Sir William Armstrong gave to the Ordnance Committee for not using the superior metal quite astounded me.
She quite panted with eagerness.
It seems quite fated that I should write this letter just like this on this warm bright day while outside a man shouts Rag-a-bone, Rag-a-bone.

s2.header: As a moderating adverb: to a certain or significant extent or degree; moderately, somewhat, rather; relatively, reasonably.
s2.n: This sense is often difficult to distinguish from sense A. II., out of which it developed; the shift in meaning being from ‘certainly having the specified character in (at least) some degree’ to ‘having the specified character in some degree (though not completely)’.

s4.def: Preceding the indefinite article. Cf. sense A. 5a.

q.qt: Had Lawyer L——n staid at home, His honour might have pass'd, with some, For quite a decent country Squire.
I thought I shouldn't like 'em very well at first; but on the whole I think it's quite a nice place.
She is likewise quite a new piece, not having exposed her goods to market above three months.
The old troglodytes, pile-villagers, and bog-people prove to be quite a respectable society.
The trim white houses‥give it quite a pretty appearance as one enters from the sea.
There was quite a sympathetic reaction in the town, which till then for some time past had done nothing but condemn him.
She‥was quite a presentable young lady.
He found that it contained quite a respectable package of bank notes.
Of course, as we have seen, he was quite a simple man.
The woman has quite a fine face, only she dresses‥in a potato sack, and wears her hair like a Liberty shopgirl's.
It seems quite a wise move; he says he's capable of looking after all the details‥, which I'm certainly not.
You may be quite a decent computer programmer, but few prospective employers will believe it if you speak poorly.
The ribbing he got was doubly unjust‥. He had quite a bad time of it without, I suspect, ever fully twigging the nature of the accusations.
Five middle-class people and two elderly labradors. In a garage. I mean, quite a roomy garage—but really.

s4.def:
Modifying adjectives, adverbs, or verbs.rare in N. Amer. usage.
With many adjectives and adverbs (esp. gradable ones), quite is ambiguous between this sense and sense A. I.; in the latter sense it now tends to collocate with particular kinds of adjective and adverb (esp. non-gradable ones).

s6.def: Modifying adjectives.

q.qt: I once,‥saw‥a large female wasp caught in the irregular web of a quite small spider.
In other words, he was quite drunk when he entered, but still more drunk at the time alluded to.
If so, who was the real one that was dreaming, and who was the one that was only a dream: it got quite interesting.
Well, that smell got inter the papers. Ther evenin' organ was quite excited about it.
Borne on the light puffs of wind this music is at times quite loud.
You shall‥when you have answered one quite small question: where is now Dr. Antal Horvath?
But the astronauts were wearing their heavy spacesuits and equipment, so even on the moon it was quite hard to move.
I only said a ‘quite’ brilliant idea, sir—not a ‘very’.
Now I feel quite sorry for the man. He is a bit of a sad case.
If you're drunk or high on goofballs, night-time TV is quite pleasant, but it can be a bit depressing.

s6.def: Modifying adverbs.

q.qt: The lithographer has done his work quite, though hardly very, well.
Theyve been proud of my poverty. Theyve even joked about it quite often.
She will manage it for you quite easily.
I did a self-portrait staring in the mirror‥. There is a faint likeness and it is quite well drawn.
Antibody levels have persisted in some vaccinees for up to 5 years, but in others the titres have declined quite rapidly.
The Moores quite frequently visited the Pipers' farmhouse at Fawley Bottom.
If it weren't for this aberrational accounting set-aside, profits would have advanced quite substantially.
Products made from pine resin are also quite widely found.

s6.def: Modifying verbs (chiefly enjoy, fancy, like).

q.qt: While of course he didn't ask me out to dinner because of my beaux yeux, he did really quite like me.
I quite like queers if it comes to that, so long as they're not on the make like Evelyn's boys.
Sneed quite liked DI Johnny Doleman, and the man treated him like an intelligent equal.
Although he personally thinks that wine tastes like iron filings, he quite enjoys watching other people drink the stuff.
I quite fancy the idea of having a househusband.

s4.def: colloq. Short for ‘quite a gentleman (lady, etc.)’; socially acceptable. Usu. in negative contexts. Also modified by quite. Now rare.

q.qt: Mrs. Fitton‥is very quite and pleasing.

Still he wasn't quite,—not quite, you know—‘not quite so much of a gentleman as I am’—Mr Walker would have said, had he spoken out freely that which he insinuated. But he contented himself with the emphasis he put upon the ‘not quite’, which expressed his meaning fully.

‘I have always liked the Dean personally,’ said Lady Sarah.‥ ‘But he isn't—he isn't quite—’ ‘No; he isn't quite—,’ said Lord George, also hesitating to pronouce the word which was understood by both of them.
Oh, she is quite quite, don't you know.‥ Her father is Sir Michael Thelliston.
Mr. Perrott‥knew that he was not ‘quite’, as Susan stated‥; not quite a gentleman she meant.
He's not ‘quite quite’, you know, but he's so clever.
That awful moment when‥one feels that one is ‘not quite’.
‘You'll find him a bit‥well, you know, not quite.‥’ The deprecating gesture sufficiently indicated what he quite wasn't.
This was supposed to be not quite quite, and British officers took no part in it.
‘She's a Lady’ (acceptable), or ‘He's not Quite’ (rejected).
Over and over you hear about folks who are uncomfortable with him, who think he's too slick or too polished or just not quite quite.

s4.def: colloq. (chiefly Brit.). As an emphatic affirmation: ‘just so’; ‘absolutely’. Cf. quite so3.

q.qt: ‘I don't hold with it, myself.’ ‘No, quite!’
‘Our likes and dislikes are not the point,’ she said. ‘The thing's impossible.’ ‘Quite,’ agreed Sir Herbert.
‘I've been supporting policies that should put an end to the whole bloody business.’ ‘Quite. And quite right.’
‘No takers,’ I said. ‘Quite. By the way, I'm sorry to say “quite” all the time but‥my work lies amongst Americans and they expect Englishmen to say it.’
‘His influence encountered no resistance.’ Quite. But what if it should happen that‥his influence did encounter resistance?

div.def: the quite contrary: something that is completely contrary (obs.).Freq. in 16th–17th centuries.

q.qt: Farre from making the man of God perfecte to all good workes, that rather the quite contrary may be confirmed.
In the Spaniards, we discerne the quite contrarie.
If he heard his neighbour tell his tale, to be sure he would tell the quite contrary.
In proportion to his deserving the quite contrary.

div.def: quite the reverse (in predicative use): the very opposite.

q.qt: Which was quite the reverse in those two‥Prelates.
With the other sex she was full of merriment and fond of joking, consequently a great favourite; towards her own sex her conduct was quite the reverse.
The rise of racism and fascism in Europe is hardly helping matters. Quite the reverse.

div.def: colloq. (chiefly Brit.). quite so (as an emphatic affirmation): ‘just so’; ‘absolutely’.

q.qt: ‘Quite so,’ assented the Doctor.
‘This maid Alice, as I understand, deposes that she‥put on a bonnet, and went out.’ ‘Quite so. And she was afterwards seen walking into Hyde-park.’
‘I know China as well as any living Englishman.’ ‘Quite so.’
Quite so, my dear chap. Then if you'll be good enough to make yourself scarce, I'll examine my patient.
‘I didn't know there was a settlement‥only a cemetery.’ ‘The burial ground: quite so.’
‘It'll be round about ten dollars.’‥ ‘Won't harm anybody,’ I agreed. ‘Quite so,’ Joe said.
Quite so, quite so. Well, I'll wait to see from you then.

div.def: colloq. (orig. U.S.) quite something: an impressive or remarkable person or thing.

q.qt: It cost the state quite something to pay for the blank ammunition that was fired off at our own men.
The thirty-eight-block Tenderloin District adjoining Canal Street was obviously quite something.
Well now, that's quite something. Thank you.
She found out that I was sleeping with someone else and she had to accept the situation which was quite something because it wasn't even a woman.
Your village seems to be quite something with the lid off.
Ideally, of course, all readers should have been included—but the work involved in analysing such a mass of information would have been quite something.
The Women's Institute itself is quite something.
Their cousin Edmund was quite something—a handsome, brave bomb-aimer stationed at Croft and delighted to meet his English cousins.
